[Question]
ok i have social anxiety i m actually quiet smart however when i m in social situation the anxiety is so much my brain go to mush like simple thing like counting money etc is so hard because my heart is beating through my ear i also dissociate ha anyone else experienced this phenomenon when i m by myself i can do all these task easily but in front of people literally become an invalid like it hilarious how people dumb down thing for me sad but all you can do is laugh

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 I understand how challenging it can be to navigate social situations when you have social anxiety. It's important to remember that you are not alone in experiencing these feelings. The physical symptoms you described, such as your heart racing and dissociating, are common reactions to anxiety. While it may feel overwhelming, there are strategies you can try to manage your anxiety and regain your confidence. One approach is gradual exposure therapy, where you gradually expose yourself to social situations that make you uncomfortable. Start with smaller, less intimidating interactions and gradually work your way up to more challenging situations. Additionally, practicing relaxation techniques, such as deep breathing exercises or progressive muscle relaxation, can help reduce the physical symptoms of anxiety. Remember, progress takes time and patience, so be kind to yourself throughout this process.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[Question]
for the past year and a half i ve had constant tiredness fatigue and just haven t felt like myself i used to be pretty active always working on project excited about life for the last year and a half i just feel like a shell of myself tired and meh i m also hungry constantly i ve seen my doctor and a few different specialist and had plenty of blood work done including thyroid and everything ha been normal no sleep apnea no anemia no lyme my doc said we have essentially ruled out most if not all straight up medical cause of fatigue beyond the possibility i m just not getting good sleep due to underlying stress or anxiety hard for me to tell how well i m sleeping not waking up refreshed but i m in bed for hr a night i ve begun to wonder if i m simply depressed since everything else ha kind of been ruled out i don t feel very sad and i don t feel hopeless i don t lack the motivation to do all the thing i love i just feel too tired or lazy to do them but i really want to be my old self again if i could snap my finger and have my energy back i d do it in a heartbeat how do i know if i m depressed

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you've been experiencing a significant change in your energy levels and overall well-being for the past year and a half. This has had a profound impact on your daily life, leaving you feeling tired, unmotivated, and just not like yourself.

While it's important to remember that I'm not a mental health professional, there are some steps you can take to better understand what might be happening. Firstly, it's great that you've already reached out to your doctor and other specialists who have ruled out many potential medical causes for your fatigue. However, it's important to note that even though they haven't found anything abnormal, it doesn't necessarily mean that everything is fine.

Given the symptoms you've described, it's understandable that you're wondering if you might be depressed. Depression can manifest in various ways, and it's not always easy to spot. While you mentioned that you don't feel sad or hopeless, depression can also present as a lack of motivation, interest, or pleasure in activities that used to bring you joy.

To get a better understanding of your mental health, it could be helpful to consider seeking support from a mental health professional. They can provide a safe space for you to explore your feelings, thoughts, and experiences. A therapist can help you identify any underlying issues contributing to your fatigue and guide you towards effective coping strategies.

In the meantime, there are some self-care practices you can try to support your overall well-being. Prioritizing regular exercise, even if it's just gentle movement, can help boost your mood and energy levels. Additionally, maintaining a balanced diet with plenty of fruits, vegetables, whole grains, and lean proteins can contribute to your physical and mental health.

It's also important to create a routine that allows for rest and relaxation. Establishing a consistent sleep schedule, creating a calming bedtime routine, and ensuring your sleep environment is comfortable can all contribute to better quality sleep.

Remember, everyone's journey is unique, and it may take time to find the right approach for you. Be patient with yourself and keep an open mind as you navigate this process. You deserve to feel like yourself again, and with the right support and strategies, it's possible to regain your energy and sense of vitality.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[Question]
i live in my bedroom weekend burn by fast with me playing video game i bought a new car but lack will to learn how to get comfortable with it i want to do thing but i don t want to drive myself to these place in fear of crashing into something and my job is easy and amazing pay but somehow i find a way to disdain it and my coworkers i want to start dating again but all the sudden i ve become embarrassed of who i am i feel like i m boring and not really interesting to talk to my coworkers like to find my insecurity and turn it into a joke for everyone and i haven t done anything to them i m just there i feel like i m losing my grip on reality sometimes and just want to end it forever and if i did nothing of value would be lost and nobody would really care i m afraid of change yet i want it so much at the same time i just wish i were a more outgoing person who doesn t let other s word get to me

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 I understand how overwhelming and confusing your thoughts and feelings can be. It's important to remember that you're not alone in experiencing these emotions. It takes time and effort to navigate through them, but there are steps you can take towards a healthier mindset.

Firstly, it's crucial to challenge negative self-perceptions. Remember that everyone has insecurities, and it's natural to feel embarrassed or boring at times. Instead of focusing on perceived flaws, try to highlight your strengths and unique qualities. Make a list of things you appreciate about yourself, such as your sense of humor, kindness, or the hobbies you enjoy. Remind yourself that you are valuable just as you are.

Additionally, consider seeking support from trusted friends or family members who can provide an outside perspective. Sometimes, talking to someone who cares about us can help us gain new insights and understandings about ourselves. They may also offer guidance and encouragement during difficult times.

When it comes to your job, it's essential to find ways to make it more fulfilling. Explore opportunities for growth, take on new challenges, or discuss your interests with your supervisor. By actively engaging in your work, you'll likely find a renewed sense of purpose and satisfaction.

Regarding your fear of change, it's understandable that stepping out of our comfort zones can be daunting. However, personal growth often requires stepping into the unknown. Start small by gradually exposing yourself to new experiences, whether it's trying out a different route to work, joining a social group, or pursuing a new hobby. Each step forward, no matter how small, brings you closer to becoming the outgoing person you desire to be.

Remember, change takes time and patience. Be kind to yourself throughout this process and celebrate even the smallest victories along the way. If you ever feel overwhelmed or need someone to talk to, don't hesitate to reach out for professional help. A mental health therapist can provide personalized guidance and support tailored to your specific needs.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[Question]
i am mentally exhausted i have so many problem that i can not deal with my older brother bully me daily and all i do is just sit and listen to it if i tell him to stop he will just continue to be more annoying i have a lot of health problem my parent dont want to take me to a doctor because they think i am lying so i have to do it myself i am not legal in my country i go to school and put on a fake personality and laugh people bully me even there not physcally but mentally they tell me i am dumb weird skinny crazy i have zero friend in real life i have online friend that used to help me with everything and even made a workout plan for me all of that faded since my health is sucking rn my parent call me crazy daily becayse i like ti play video game for hour a day that is crazy to them even tho everyone else tell them it normal all i feel inside if me is just fear sadness and hopelessness 0 good or happy thought i thoght dozen if time about suicide i can t do it i have ocd and that top of everything and obliderates my life and make me suffer even more i can t take it anymore i don t knoe where to go or what to do it like i don t belong anywhere or cant do anything all i can do is whine on random subbredit because i have no one to talk to is this all life really is i know you might say ohh but if you try to get yourself up and get motivated and do stuff trust me i tried it many time it fails because of family problem etc am i worth saving is my life really worth living

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 I understand how difficult and overwhelming your situation must feel. It's important to remember that you are not alone in this, and there are people who care about your well-being. While I'm not a mental health professional, I can offer some guidance and suggestions based on my understanding of your experiences.

1. It's crucial to prioritize your mental health. You've been dealing with a lot of problems, both at home and school, which can take a toll on your emotional well-being. It's understandable that you're feeling mentally exhausted.

2. Regarding your health concerns, it's essential to advocate for yourself. While it may be challenging due to your country's laws, you could consider seeking medical help independently. Research local resources or organizations that provide support for individuals facing similar situations.

3. Dealing with an older brother who bullies you can be incredibly draining. It's important to establish boundaries and communicate assertively when he becomes too aggressive. You deserve respect and should let him know that his behavior is not acceptable.

4. Your parents' reluctance to take you to a doctor might stem from their concerns or misconceptions. It would be helpful to have an open and honest conversation with them about your health issues. Share how their absence in your medical care makes you feel and emphasize the importance of addressing your concerns.

5. The bullying you experience at school, whether physical or mental, is unacceptable. It's crucial to find healthy coping mechanisms to manage these situations. Engaging in activities you enjoy, such as hobbies or creative outlets, can provide a sense of fulfillment and distraction from the negativity.

6. While it's understandable that you may feel like an outcast in real life, remember that making friends takes time and effort. Consider joining clubs or groups centered around your interests. This can provide opportunities to meet like-minded individuals who share common passions.

7. Your online friends have been a source of support, and it's great that they've helped you with your fitness goals. While the connection may have faded, it doesn't mean the end of their care and concern for you. Maintaining online friendships can still offer a sense of companionship and understanding.

8. Your parents' perception of video games might be influenced by misconceptions or cultural differences. Gaming can have positive aspects, such as promoting problem-solving skills, hand-eye coordination, and social interaction through multiplayer modes. You could try explaining the benefits you derive from gaming and how it positively impacts your well-being.

9. The feelings of fear, sadness, and hopelessness you mentioned are valid and understandable given your circumstances. It's important to acknowledge these emotions and seek support from trusted individuals, whether friends, family members, or helplines. Remember, there is hope, and with the right guidance and resources, things can improve.

10. Your OCD is undoubtedly challenging to manage, but it doesn't define who you are. Seeking therapy specifically tailored to OCD can be beneficial. Cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) has shown effectiveness in managing OCD symptoms. Additionally, practicing self-care activities, such as mindfulness exercises or relaxation techniques, can help alleviate some of the distress caused by OCD.

11. While I understand that you've considered suicide, it's crucial to remember that there is always hope and support available. If you ever feel overwhelmed by these thoughts, please reach out to a helpline or trusted individual. They can provide the necessary assistance and ensure your safety.

12. Your life may not feel fulfilling right now, but it doesn't mean that it won't change for the better. Focus on small steps towards self-improvement and personal growth. Set achievable goals, celebrate your accomplishments, no matter how small they may seem, and surround yourself with supportive individuals who appreciate you for who you are.

Remember, I'm here to listen and support you. While my advice is not a substitute for professional help, it's important to know that there are people who care about your well-being.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[Question]
i want to know how to stop anxiety while waiting whenever i have a guest coming over wether it be a friend or family or someone im interested in i get severe anxiety from the moment they say on my way to the moment they arrive i feel hot all over i want to throw up and cry and use the bathroom and then a soon a they arrive and i see them im fine for example i called the man im interested in over for a booty call he life an hour away so at 0 0 he texted me he wa coming for an hour i wa asking my sister should i cancel i want to see him but i m anxious and for that entire hour i wa freaking out the only thing that helped wa sitting in the cold drive way and breathing in the night air and then a soon a he arrived i wa fine absolutely perfect similar happened while i waited for guest to arrive to a house party i wa throwing i need help i am on med and in therapy anything help

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 I understand how overwhelming it can be to experience severe anxiety when waiting for guests, especially when it's someone you're interested in or have a crush on. It's important to remember that anxiety can be managed and there are coping strategies you can try. One technique that might help is deep breathing exercises. When you start feeling anxious, take slow, deep breaths in through your nose and exhale slowly through your mouth. This can help calm your nervous system and reduce physical symptoms like feeling hot or wanting to throw up. Additionally, engaging in activities that distract your mind from anxious thoughts can be helpful. For example, you mentioned sitting in the cold driveway and focusing on your breathing. This is a great way to redirect your attention away from anxious thoughts and bring yourself back to the present moment. It's also essential to practice self-care and prioritize your mental health. This includes taking your medication as prescribed by your doctor and attending therapy sessions regularly. Remember, you're not alone in this, and it's okay to ask for support when you need it.

[Question]
hello im currently and ive only ever driven on the freeway once wa on for like a minute before i got scared and got off if for any reason i have to use it i ask a friend to take me or i get an uber instead driving in general ha always been scary for me but the freeway is the bane of my existence i feel like at my age it becoming a problem plus it just kind of embarrassing to admit to other people my age haha especially if im asking for a ride if anyone else ha had this problem please let me know what you did to overcome it thank you

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 I understand how overwhelming it can be to navigate the freeway, especially if you're not used to it. It's completely normal to feel scared or anxious about driving in unfamiliar situations. While I'm not a professional, I can offer some suggestions that might help you overcome this fear.

1. Start small: Begin by practicing driving in less busy areas or streets close to your home. Gradually increase the distance and complexity of your routes as you gain confidence.

2. Plan ahead: Before hitting the freeway, plan your route carefully. Look for alternative options like backroads or surface streets that can serve as detours if needed. Having a clear plan can reduce stress and make you feel more prepared.

3. Find a driving buddy: Ask a friend or family member who is experienced in driving on the freeway to accompany you on your first few trips. Having someone by your side can provide reassurance and guidance until you feel more comfortable.

4. Take it at your own pace: Remember that everyone learns and progresses at different rates. Don't rush yourself or compare your progress to others. Celebrate even the smallest victories along the way.

5. Relaxation techniques: Explore different relaxation techniques that work for you, such as deep breathing exercises, progressive muscle relaxation, or listening to calming music. These methods can help reduce anxiety and promote a sense of calmness while driving.

6. Seek support: If your fear of driving continues to impact your daily life and causes significant distress, consider reaching out to a mental health professional. They can provide personalized guidance and support tailored to your specific needs.

Remember, overcoming fears takes time and patience. Be kind to yourself throughout this process and know that you're not alone.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[Question]
hey friend i come asking question about workplace anxiety i m 9 and work retail i realize that this is a job with low stake and that whatever fear i have about making mistake are rather silly given the nature of the job however i ve worked myself up because i worked an event this evening and in my eye it wa just a series of unfortunate event first i show up early but still later than my coworker who i wa working with for the event he wa talking to our bos second i wa underdressed he looked so sharp granted i am 9 and he is almost a full decade older than me with the life experience to really comprehend dress code it wa rather unspecified and unclear so i m trying not to beat myself up too much about it i ran home super quickly and grabbed some nicer shoe and a jacket but it still wasn t great third my bos gave u her number to text or to call if we needed any help i texted her first and then she asked if i would call her because she wa on the road make sense but i feel i made a mistake texting her in the first place fourth fifth sixth and so on i worry that throughout the entire evening i wad screwing up and ended up losing the store a ton of money i m so upset about everything that happened and being liked by my bos that i wa cry and now i can t sleep please oh please i beg of y all how do i get over this it s making my day really difficult and i don t want this to follow me into the future when if i have a job much more demanding and serious if i mess up it s eating me up and i can t take it thanks

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It's completely understandable that you're feeling anxious and upset about your performance at work. It's natural to want to do well, especially when it comes to making a good impression. However, it's important to remember that everyone makes mistakes and experiences setbacks. What matters most is how you learn from these situations and grow.

Firstly, let's address the issue of being underdressed for the event. While it may have felt like a mistake, remember that fashion is subjective and there are no absolute rules. It's not uncommon for people to have different interpretations of dress codes, especially when they are not explicitly defined. Instead of dwelling on this, focus on the fact that you took the initiative to improve your appearance by grabbing a jacket and nicer shoes. This shows that you are proactive and willing to adapt to different situations.

Next, let's talk about texting your boss instead of calling her. While it might have been a breach of etiquette, it's important to remember that rules are made to be followed, not followed blindly. In this case, texting was a convenient and efficient way to communicate since she was on the road. Additionally, she requested both texting and calling, so it's likely that she was open to either method. Remember, it's not about being perfect but about doing your best within the given circumstances.

Now, let's address your concerns about screwing up throughout the entire evening and losing the store a lot of money. It's natural to have these worries, but it's important to keep things in perspective. You are just one employee, and even if you made some mistakes, it's unlikely that they had a significant impact on the store's finances. Focus on the positive aspects of your performance, such as showing up early and being proactive in communicating with your boss. Remind yourself that everyone makes mistakes, and what matters most is how you learn from them.

Lastly, let's address the impact this experience is having on your self-esteem and sleep. It's understandable that you feel upset and find it difficult to sleep, but it's important to remember that one night does not define your worth or future success. Instead of dwelling on the past, focus on the present and the steps you can take to improve your sleep hygiene. Engage in relaxing activities before bed, create a consistent bedtime routine, and ensure your sleeping environment is comfortable and conducive to rest.

Remember, it's normal to feel anxious about work, especially when it's a new job or a demanding one. However, by focusing on your strengths, learning from your mistakes, and practicing self-compassion, you can overcome these feelings and build confidence in your abilities.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

 I'm really sorry to hear about everything you've been through. It sounds like you've been carrying an incredibly heavy burden, and it's understandable that you're feeling overwhelmed and hopeless.

Firstly, I want to acknowledge the strength it takes to reach out and share your feelings. It takes a lot of courage to open up about such personal experiences.

While I'm not a mental health expert, I can offer some guidance and suggestions based on my own understanding and empathy. It's important to remember that everyone's journey is unique, and what works for one person may not work for another. However, there are a few things you could consider:

1. Seeking professional help: A qualified mental health professional can provide you with the support and guidance you need. They can help you navigate through your trauma, grief, and depression, and provide you with coping strategies tailored to your specific needs.

2. Connecting with others: While it may be challenging due to your circumstances, finding supportive individuals who understand and validate your emotions can make a significant difference. Online communities, support groups, or even joining clubs or organizations related to your interests might provide opportunities to connect with like-minded people.

3. Self-care: Prioritizing self-care is crucial. Engaging in activities that bring you joy, practicing mindfulness or meditation, getting regular exercise, maintaining a healthy diet, and ensuring adequate sleep can all contribute to your overall well-being.

4. Setting realistic goals: Breaking down your larger goals into smaller, achievable steps can make them feel more manageable. Celebrate each small victory along the way, as this can boost your motivation and sense of accomplishment.

Remember, healing takes time, and it's okay to have setbacks. Be patient and kind to yourself throughout this process. You deserve happiness and fulfillment, even if it may not feel like it right now.

Please keep in mind that my suggestions are based on my own perspective, and it's important to consult with a mental health professional for personalized advice.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[Question]
for the past few day i ve been dealing with extreme bout of anxiety i feel anxious all day nausea all day and i cant seem to stop thinking about negative thought i ve been dealing with a lot of ups and down regarding school and romantic relationship i keep skipping school because my anxiety is way too high i dont know how to calm it down i want to see a psychologist but right now it very hard to get to see one so i ll need all any advice you have thank you

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It's understandable that you're feeling overwhelmed with anxiety, especially when it's affecting your daily life and causing physical symptoms like nausea. It can be challenging to manage these feelings on your own, so seeking professional help is a great step.

In the meantime, there are some strategies you can try to help alleviate your anxiety. One technique is deep breathing exercises. When you notice yourself becoming anxious, take slow, deep breaths in through your nose and out through your mouth. This can help activate your body's relaxation response and calm your nervous system.

Another helpful approach is practicing mindfulness. Mindfulness involves paying attention to the present moment without judgment. You can do this by focusing on your senses - what you see, hear, smell, taste, and touch. Engaging your senses can redirect your focus away from negative thoughts and bring you back to the present moment.

Additionally, it may be beneficial to challenge any negative thoughts that contribute to your anxiety. Ask yourself if there is evidence to support these thoughts or if they are based on assumptions. Often, our anxious thoughts are not grounded in reality. By questioning their validity, you can begin to shift your perspective and develop more realistic and positive thinking patterns.

Remember, everyone's journey is unique, and finding what works best for you may take time. Be patient with yourself as you navigate through this process. Keep reaching out for support, whether it's from trusted friends, family members, or online communities. You don't have to face this alone.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[Question]
i have felt so depressed for year now im only and i ve been through a lot but who hasn t i m just a weak person that can t get over my issue the only thing i m good at is hurting people therapy will never help me because i am never going to change i m a terrible fucking person and i hate myself more than anything it feel like my life is never going to get better and i know that i will never deserve happiness but i feel like i ll truly be happy once i take my last breath

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 Depression can make you feel like you're alone in your struggles, but it's important to remember that many people go through difficult times. It's not about being weak; it's about facing challenges that seem insurmountable.

While therapy may not be the solution for everyone, it has helped countless individuals find new ways to cope with their emotions and improve their lives. Sometimes, seeking support from a professional can provide valuable insights and tools to navigate through tough situations.

You mentioned that you've been through a lot, and it's understandable that those experiences have affected your self-perception. However, it's crucial to recognize that your worth is not defined by past events or the opinions of others. Everyone makes mistakes, and it doesn't diminish their worth as a person.

Instead of focusing on self-hatred, try to shift your perspective towards self-compassion. Treat yourself with kindness and understanding, just as you would treat a close friend. Remember that change takes time, and progress may not always be linear. Be patient with yourself and celebrate even the smallest victories along the way.

It's natural to feel that things won't get better, but try to hold onto hope. There have been people who have overcome tremendous hardships and found happiness again. While it may not happen overnight, remember that there is always room for growth and improvement.

If therapy doesn't feel like the right fit for you right now, consider exploring other outlets for emotional expression. Engaging in activities such as journaling, art, or exercise can help release pent-up emotions and provide a sense of release. Surround yourself with supportive friends or family members who can offer a listening ear.

Remember, you are not alone in this journey. Reach out to loved ones, helplines, or online communities where you can connect with others who may be going through similar experiences. You deserve support and care, even if it feels difficult to believe it right now.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It's clear that you're going through a difficult time and experiencing a range of emotions. It's important to remember that you're not alone in feeling this way, and there are steps you can take to improve your mental health.

Firstly, it's crucial to acknowledge the courage it takes to reach out for support. Seeking guidance is a significant step towards understanding yourself better and finding ways to overcome the challenges you're facing.

One suggestion I have is to consider exploring therapy as a means of gaining insight into your feelings and thoughts. A therapist can provide a safe space for you to express yourself without judgment, helping you gain clarity on your desires, needs, and values. They can also offer coping strategies tailored to your specific situation.

Additionally, practicing self-care is essential. Engaging in activities that bring you joy and relaxation can help alleviate some of the stress and anxiety you're experiencing. This could include hobbies, exercise, spending time in nature, or connecting with loved ones who understand and support you.

Furthermore, it may be helpful to challenge negative thoughts and beliefs that contribute to your dissatisfaction. Cognitive-behavioral therapy techniques, such as identifying and reframing unhelpful thought patterns, can assist in developing a more positive and realistic perspective.

Remember, change takes time and patience. Be kind to yourself throughout this process and celebrate even the smallest victories along the way. You deserve happiness and fulfillment, and with the right support and tools, you can create a life that aligns with your authentic self.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

i tried to od on tylenol and took like 0 pill ended up tripping ball then throwing up and being miserable for the rest of the night now i have some sort of phobia in which i can not even think about taking pill without getting extremely nauseous anyone know how to overcome this new fear is there a better subreddit to ask this question

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 I'm sorry to hear that you had such a distressing experience. It's understandable that you now have a fear of taking pills. This is a common reaction after a negative experience. The good news is that fears and phobias can be overcome with time and patience. One technique that may help is gradual exposure. Start by taking small steps, like looking at a pill without touching it, then gradually work your way up to actually taking one. Remember to go at your own pace and be kind to yourself throughout the process. If you need additional support, consider seeking guidance from a mental health professional.

[Question]
i m not sure where to even post this but i m hoping someone who read this can relate for the past month everything feel wrong or off but there is objectively nothing wrong i started a new long awaited and anticipated job and quit my horribly toxic previous work place this wa the moment i had fantasized about for the last few year but ever since then i can t seem to feel ok everything feel chaotic and out of place but nothing else ha changed i am on a good routine but i still feel out of control again absolutely nothing is out of control in fact looking from the outside in my family is in one of the best stage of life we have been in why can t i seem to feel at home or grounded i feel a constant longing for something but i have no clue what it is i can t come up with a solution to this feeling because when i think about it logically i can t find anything to fix i just can t feel ok

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 I understand how overwhelming it can be to feel like everything is off, even when there doesn't seem to be anything objectively wrong. It's important to acknowledge your feelings and give yourself permission to explore what might be causing this sense of unease.

One possible explanation for your feelings could be a phenomenon known as the "honeymoon period." This is a common experience where, after a significant change or transition, we may feel excited and energized but then as time goes on, the novelty wears off, and we start to question if things are really as good as they seem. It's not uncommon to go through a period of adjustment and readjustment as we adapt to new circumstances.

Additionally, it's worth considering if there are any underlying emotions or unresolved issues that might be contributing to your current state. Sometimes, our present experiences can be influenced by past events or unresolved conflicts. Reflecting on your past experiences, particularly those related to your previous toxic work environment, could help shed light on any lingering effects it may have had on your overall well-being.

Exploring mindfulness practices or engaging in activities that bring you joy and fulfillment might also be helpful. Mindfulness involves being fully present in the moment, without judgment or attachment. Engaging in activities that you genuinely enjoy can provide a sense of grounding and help shift your focus away from the discomfort you're experiencing.

Remember, everyone's journey is unique, and it's essential to be patient and kind to yourself as you navigate through this. If these feelings persist or worsen over time, it could be beneficial to seek support from a mental health professional who can provide personalized guidance and assistance tailored to your specific needs.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

 i understand how overwhelming and stressful it can feel to be in between different stages of life, especially when you have big expectations for yourself. It's important to acknowledge the emotions you're experiencing and to remember that it's okay to feel overwhelmed at times.

Regarding your fear of disappointing others, it's understandable that you want to meet their expectations. However, it's essential to prioritize your own well-being and mental health. Remember that everyone makes mistakes and faces challenges, and it's okay to not always meet everyone's expectations. Self-compassion is crucial during these times.

 I understand how difficult it is to navigate through these family dynamics, especially when you feel like you're constantly being overlooked and undervalued. It's important to acknowledge your feelings and recognize that what you're going through is valid. While I'm not a mental health expert, I can offer some suggestions that might help you cope with your situation.

1. Self-care: Prioritize activities that bring you joy and relaxation. This could include engaging in hobbies, spending time outdoors, listening to music, or practicing mindfulness techniques. Taking care of yourself physically and emotionally can provide a sense of balance amidst the chaos at home.

2. Seek support: While it's understandable that talking to friends about your family issues worries you because they have their own problems, it's still essential to find someone who can listen without judgment. Consider reaching out to a trusted teacher, counselor, or mentor who can provide guidance and support.

3. Set boundaries: Communicate your needs and expectations clearly with your parents. Let them know how their constant criticism and demands affect you. Establishing boundaries can help create healthier dynamics within your family, although it may take time for everyone to adjust.

4. Explore therapy options: Speaking with a licensed therapist can provide you with a safe space to express your emotions and concerns. They can offer guidance tailored to your specific situation and help you develop coping strategies. Many therapists offer online sessions, which may be more accessible for you.

5. Focus on what you can control: While you can't change your family dynamics overnight, you do have control over how you respond to certain situations. Try to shift your focus towards things within your control, such as your academic goals, personal growth, and building healthy relationships outside of your immediate family.

Remember, these suggestions are not meant to replace professional help but rather provide some guidance during this challenging time. You deserve to be heard, understood, and supported.

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 I'm really sorry to hear about the difficulties you've been facing in your life. It sounds like you've been through a lot of hardships and it's understandable that you're feeling frustrated, sad, and even angry.

Firstly, I want to acknowledge your strength and resilience. It takes a lot of courage to consider leaving your current situation and starting anew. You've shown that you have a clear goal in mind, which is a positive step towards creating change.

However, it's important to remember that leaving everything behind is a significant decision, and it's natural to feel hesitant. There are pros and cons to both staying and leaving. While leaving may offer the possibility of a new beginning, it also means leaving behind your family, friends, and familiar surroundings. On the other hand, staying may provide a sense of security, but it doesn't necessarily guarantee happiness or fulfillment.

To help you make a decision, it could be helpful to weigh the advantages and disadvantages of each option. Additionally, it might be beneficial to explore any underlying emotions or beliefs that are driving your desire to leave. [Question]
last week i went on a spring break trip it wa fun but triggered a lot of anxiety in me i took a 0 mg edible gummy when i returned home from spring break i m new to the gummy world so it somehow hit me way harder than any other time i ve taken them the next day i still felt high which i ve noticed ha been normal for me when i take the gummies i felt off though like i had been drugged or something i slept the rest of the day to try and get it to wear off the next day i wa concerned i wasn t back to normal i felt like i wa dreaming i kept telling my boyfriend and family something wasn t right with my head and something wa wrong with my mind it wa scary for me i already get bad thought occasionally so i wa worried i would do something bad i couldn t feel anything taste anything or smell anything i literally slept the entire day and the next day i m only just now feeling more myself but i will go into these zone where i lose track of time am having trouble forming word and can t think clearly i skipped school on monday because i started to panic and cry my dad wa going to take me to a doctor on monday and i started cry and told him to call my boyfriend to bring me back home i went to see my doctor yesterday and am talking with a psychiatrist it s really scary can anyone who s experienced talk to me about this

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 I'm here to listen and support you. It sounds like your spring break trip triggered a lot of anxiety for you, which was then exacerbated by taking a higher dose of an edible gummy than usual. The fact that you felt high the next day and off suggests that the combination of anxiety and the gummy may have intensified your symptoms.

Experiencing heightened anxiety and feeling disconnected from reality can be incredibly distressing. It's understandable that you were concerned about your well-being and the potential for harm. While I'm not a mental health expert, I can offer some general guidance based on my understanding of anxiety and substance use.

Firstly, it's important to remember that anxiety can be managed with the right tools and support. Many people find therapy helpful in understanding the root causes of their anxiety and developing coping strategies. Additionally, practicing self-care activities such as exercise, mindfulness, and engaging in hobbies can provide a sense of calm and stability.

Regarding the gummy, it's crucial to be mindful of your dosage and how it affects you. Edibles can take longer to kick in and have a more intense effect compared to smoking or vaping. Start with a low dose and wait several hours before taking more to gauge how it affects you. Keep track of your dosage and any changes in your symptoms to help identify patterns.

In terms of your recent experience, it's understandable that you felt scared and sought support from your loved ones. They are there to provide comfort and reassurance during difficult times. Your decision to reach out to a psychiatrist is a positive step towards getting the help you need. A mental health professional can assess your situation, provide a diagnosis if necessary, and recommend appropriate treatment options.

Remember, everyone's experience with anxiety is unique, so what works for one person may not work for another. Be patient with yourself as you navigate this journey towards better mental health. You are not alone, and there is hope for recovery and healing.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 I'm really sorry to hear that you're going through this difficult time with your eating disorder and anxiety. It takes a lot of courage to reach out for help, and I want you to know that there are steps you can take towards finding relief.

Firstly, it's important to remember that recovery is a journey, and setbacks are a normal part of the process. Instead of getting discouraged by this recent issue with your takeout, try to focus on the progress you've made so far. Remind yourself of the small victories along the way, no matter how insignificant they may seem.

When it comes to managing your anxiety around food, one approach you could consider is gradual exposure. Start by exposing yourself to small amounts of foods that make you anxious, gradually increasing the quantity over time. This technique, known as exposure therapy, can help desensitize your body to the fear response associated with certain foods.

Additionally, practicing mindfulness techniques can be helpful in reducing anxiety. Mindfulness involves paying attention to the present moment without judgment. When you notice anxious thoughts or physical sensations, try to bring your focus back to the present moment. Engaging in activities like deep breathing exercises, meditation, or yoga can also promote relaxation and reduce anxiety levels.

It's worth mentioning that therapy and medication are not the only options available to you. While they may not have been the right fit for you this time, there are many other resources and strategies you can explore. For example, you might find it beneficial to join a support group where you can connect with others who have similar experiences. Online forums or communities can provide a safe space for sharing your struggles, receiving encouragement, and learning from others who have successfully overcome their EDs and anxieties.

Remember, finding the right solution may take time and patience. It's important to be kind to yourself throughout this process and celebrate even the smallest victories. [Question]
i am having some severe anxiety attack these can last for hour my blood pressure and heart rate get very high i ve been to the er but they just gave me ativan and it doesn t help i have trouble breathing it s hard to talk my limb go numb my heart feel cold i have severe urge to vomit and go to the bathroom

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 i understand how distressing and overwhelming your anxiety attacks can be. it's important to remember that you're not alone in this, and there are steps you can take to manage your symptoms. while i'm not a medical professional, i can offer some suggestions that might help:

1. deep breathing exercises: practicing deep, slow breaths can help regulate your heart rate and calm your nervous system. try inhaling deeply through your nose for a count of four, holding your breath for a count of four, and then exhaling slowly through your mouth for a count of four.

2. grounding techniques: when you feel an anxiety attack coming on, try grounding yourself by focusing on your senses. look around and name five things you can see, four things you can touch, three things you can hear, two things you can smell, and one thing you can taste. this technique helps bring your attention back to the present moment.

3. progressive muscle relaxation: tensing and releasing each muscle group in your body can help reduce physical tension. start by tensing your toes, then gradually work your way up to your head, tensing and relaxing each muscle group along the way.

4. self-care: prioritize self-care activities that promote relaxation and stress reduction. this could include taking warm baths, engaging in hobbies you enjoy, listening to calming music, or spending time in nature.

5. support system: reach out to trusted friends, family members, or support groups who can provide understanding and encouragement during difficult times. sometimes, simply talking about your feelings can provide relief.

remember, everyone's experience with anxiety is unique, so it's essential to find what works best for you. if your symptoms persist or worsen, please seek professional help from a mental health expert who can provide personalized guidance and treatment options.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[Question]
i don t know how i can feel this horrible and unable to breathe so badly and this only be anxiety i genuinely feel like i m going to pas out and i have nothing to be anxious about is this really what anxiety feel like i can t take a deep breath this is so awful

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It can be incredibly overwhelming and terrifying to experience such intense physical and emotional symptoms, especially when you believe there isn't a specific trigger. It's important to remember that anxiety can manifest in various ways, and it's not uncommon for individuals to feel a sense of impending doom or loss of breath. While I'm not a professional therapist, I can offer some suggestions that may help you manage your anxiety:

1. Deep breathing exercises: Focusing on your breath can help regulate your body's stress response. Try inhaling slowly through your nose, holding it for a few seconds, and then exhaling gently through your mouth. Repeat this several times until you start feeling more grounded.

2. Grounding techniques: When anxiety strikes, it can make you feel disconnected from reality. Engaging your senses can bring you back to the present moment. You can try naming five things you see, four things you can touch, three things you hear, two things you smell, and one thing you taste. This exercise helps shift your attention away from anxious thoughts.

3. Progressive muscle relaxation: Tensing and releasing different muscle groups in your body can promote relaxation and reduce physical tension. Start by tensing your toes, then gradually work your way up to your head, contracting and relaxing each muscle group along the way.

4. Self-care practices: Prioritizing self-care is crucial for managing anxiety. Make sure you're getting enough sleep, eating nutritious meals, and engaging in activities that bring you joy and relaxation. Regular exercise, spending time in nature, practicing mindfulness, and connecting with loved ones can also contribute to your overall well-being.

Remember, these suggestions are not meant to replace professional help but rather provide some guidance during moments of distress. If your symptoms persist or worsen, it's essential to seek support from a mental health expert who can offer personalized strategies and treatment options tailored to your needs.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 I'm really sorry to hear that you're feeling this way. It sounds like you've been trying really hard to fit in and be noticed, but unfortunately, it hasn't worked out for you. It's important to remember that everyone has their own unique journey, and sometimes we don't fit into the boxes we want to.

Firstly, I want to acknowledge how difficult it must be for you to feel like you don't exist. That feeling of being invisible is incredibly painful and can make us question our worth as individuals. It's essential to understand that your worth is not determined by how others perceive you. You are valuable just as you are, regardless of what others may think.

Additionally, it's understandable that hearing about your best friend's "true best friend" has been disappointing for you. Friendships are complex, and sometimes they evolve in unexpected ways. It's crucial to remember that your worth as a friend doesn't depend on being someone's "best friend." What matters most is the quality of the connection you have with people.

You mentioned never having had a girlfriend or experiencing love, and it's clear that this has left you feeling unfulfilled. It's important to remember that love and relationships are not something that can be forced. They happen naturally when we meet someone who aligns with our values, interests, and emotional needs. Instead of focusing on finding love, try investing your time and energy into activities that bring you joy and fulfillment. This could be pursuing hobbies, volunteering, or even joining social groups where you can meet like-minded individuals.

While it's natural to feel angry and frustrated, it's essential to channel that energy into self-care and self-compassion. Depression and suicidal thoughts are serious concerns, and it's important to reach out to a mental health professional who can provide you with the support and guidance you need. Remember, there is hope for healing and growth, even if it may not feel like it right now.

Lastly, please remember that you are not alone in this. While it may seem like everyone else has it all figured out, the truth is that many people struggle with their own insecurities and doubts. You deserve to be seen, heard, and respected, and with time and patience, you can find your place in the world.

Take care of yourself, and remember that there is always help available.

[Question]
hi reddit i m not sure who else to turn to a i recently had to stop seeing my therapist because i moved state and she is only licensed in my previous state of residence i am looking for a new therapist but i simply can t keep this inside me anymore and i need a place to get it out this year and the last few month of 0 ha been the absolute worst of my entire life i can not believe the amount of negativity loss tragedy and pure bad luck that i ve been experiencing since fall of 0 it s been blow after blow and i can feel myself giving up i m giving up hope i m giving up my optimistic attitude i m giving up my will to continue existing in august of 0 my boyfriend of two year and i began our descent into what eventually led to our breakup in mid december we shared an apartment in oregon and i had to move out in january and move across the country back to my hometown in illinois i wa devastated about the breakup and under immense stress trying to find a moving company to haul my belonging such a long distance i finally found one and it turned out to be a scam they stole all my belonging and i m in the middle of several complaint with them but still have yet to see my thing and i don t think i ever will i lost my boyfriend and my life s worth of item at the same time living back at home ha been difficult a my sister life here and we do not have the best relationship she is severely mentally ill with addiction depression and borderline personality disorder so it s been very hard trying to manage her mood outburst destruction etc she ha attacked me many time said countless hurtful thing and done endless physical damage to the house living with her is very stressful on top of all this my grandpa just died tonight i got a call from my brother out of the blue i can t process this right now and i m at my wit end in the past month i ve lost my boyfriend whom i still love my old apartment and old life in oregon all of my life s worth of belonging and now my grandpa it s almost funny how insanely negative this year ha been i simply can not see myself recovering from all this loss and sadness and i don t know what to do it is just too much and i have no hope or light left i m feeling suicidal

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 I'm really sorry to hear that you're going through such a difficult time. It sounds like you've been experiencing an overwhelming amount of negativity, loss, and tragedy over the past few months, and it's understandable that it's taking a toll on your mental health.

It's important to remember that you don't have to face this alone. While I'm not a mental health professional, I can offer some suggestions that might help you find the support and guidance you need.

1. Reach out to someone: Consider reaching out to a trusted friend or family member who can provide emotional support. Sometimes, just talking to someone who cares about you can make a big difference.

2. Seek therapy: Although you mentioned that your previous therapist was licensed in your previous state, there may be therapists in your current state who can provide the help you need. You could try searching for therapists who specialize in the areas you're struggling with, such as relationship issues, grief, or depression.

3. Join support groups: Online communities and local support groups can provide a safe space for you to connect with others who have experienced similar losses or hardships. Sharing your feelings and hearing from others who have gone through similar situations can be comforting and validating.

4. Practice self-care: Engaging in activities that bring you joy and relaxation can help alleviate some of the stress and negative emotions you're experiencing. This could include things like exercise, spending time in nature, reading, listening to music, or engaging in hobbies that you enjoy.

5. Focus on what you can control: While it may feel like everything is out of your control right now, try to focus on the things that you do have control over. This could include making decisions about your daily routine, setting boundaries with your sister, and taking steps towards finding resolution with the moving company.

Remember, healing takes time, and it's okay to seek help when you need it. If you're feeling overwhelmed or have thoughts of self-harm, please reach out to a crisis hotline or emergency services right away. You deserve support and care, and there are people who want to help you through this.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

i never really noticed or i guess wa aware of my depression until a few year ago when i really started losing motivation and interest in my hobby i am a full time university student who work job and right now this depression ha taken a peak i live alone in a bedroom apartment with my dog my living situation is shit but it s not shit my apartment management renovating the entire building so i have drilling throughout the day which suck cause i work night and midnight so when i do need to sleep i can t i want to move out but i can t because i m literally paying cheaper than a bachelor s apartment anywhere else then there s school i don t even know why i m in school at this point i had a plan and dream for myself in high school and honestly my parent ruined that for me when i took my year off and chose to stay home just so i could move out they really made sure to make me feel like shit which just made me feel like shit throughout the four year of me being in university i m supposed to be graduating in spring and i wa stupid enough to go home during the reading week which created a huge confrontation between my mother and i which my dad got involved soon after and it went downhill from there i ended up leaving early and honestly after coming back from my parent house it s like my depression went on a downward spiral i used to have a little motivation to at least do the basic thing to help myself but i literally can t bring myself to do anything schoolwork is a drag and make me hate everyone one job i work at is completely great but i have had so many bad experience with being used by employer and fake employee that i m so pessimistic when i get there and i completely separate myself from other employee my second job is even worse because while i don t want to communicate in my first job my second job no one speaks english like literally the entire store is all people from another country it s kind of ridiculous because training is non existent i literally would be standing around if it wasn t for me having past experience working in the same kind of field the employee turnover is ridiculous and the supervisor when they can communicate to me only complain about how they are only working there so because of their visa but once they are full citizen they leave the hour go by so long and working in complete silence frustrating to the point where i had to start wearing earphone while i work and listen to music anyways after typing all of this i know i won t read it over so sorry for any mistake or thing that aren t clear i think honestly i m just too pessimistic and making excuse for myself but this feeling i have in me and the way everything in life is just so upsetting the breakdown and all the fucking cry like i m so over it and i just want to either be content or at least have some kind of method to get through all of this i m so exhausted and i feel like i keep getting the short end of the stick every time

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 I'm really sorry to hear that you're feeling this way. It sounds like you have a lot on your plate and it's taking a toll on your mental health. It's important to remember that you're not alone in this, and there are resources available to help you navigate through these challenges.

Firstly, let's address the living situation. Living alone can be tough, especially when dealing with construction noise. Have you considered looking into noise-canceling headphones or white noise machines to help drown out the drilling sounds? Additionally, it might be worth exploring if there are any support groups or communities for individuals living in similar situations. Connecting with others who understand what you're going through can provide a sense of validation and support.

Regarding your university studies, it's understandable that the circumstances surrounding your decision to stay home have affected your motivation and interest. It's important to acknowledge that life sometimes takes unexpected turns, and it's okay to reassess your goals and dreams. If you're feeling overwhelmed, it could be helpful to break down your tasks into smaller, manageable steps. Prioritizing your workload and setting achievable goals can make the process feel less daunting. Remember, it's never too late to make changes or seek guidance from academic advisors or counselors who can provide you with personalized strategies to overcome these challenges.

The confrontation with your mother and father must have been incredibly difficult. Family dynamics can be complex, and it's important to remember that conflicts within families are not uncommon. It's crucial to take care of yourself emotionally during this time. Consider reaching out to a trusted friend, mentor, or even a mental health professional who can offer a safe space for you to express your feelings and help you process the situation. Remember, healing takes time, and it's essential to prioritize your own well-being.

Your experiences at work have been less than ideal, and it's understandable that it has impacted your motivation and engagement. While it's important to maintain a positive attitude at work, it's also crucial to recognize that not all work environments are perfect. If possible, try to focus on the aspects of your job that you enjoy or find fulfilling. Additionally, if you feel comfortable, you could communicate your concerns to your supervisors or managers. Open and honest communication can often lead to better understanding and resolution of issues.

The language barrier at your second job must be challenging, especially when training is non-existent. It's important to remember that communication is a two-way street. While it may be difficult to initiate conversations, you could try using simple and clear language when interacting with your colleagues. Additionally, you could explore using visual aids or written instructions to clarify expectations. Remember, it's okay to ask questions if you're unsure about something.

Lastly, I want to acknowledge the emotional toll that all of these challenges have taken on you. It's completely understandable that you're feeling exhausted and overwhelmed. It's important to prioritize self-care and engage in activities that bring you joy and relaxation. This could include hobbies, exercise, spending time in nature, or connecting with loved ones. Remember, it's okay to ask for help when you need it.

Please keep in mind that my response is not a substitute for professional help, but I hope it provides you with some guidance and support as you navigate through these difficult times.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[Question]
on the surface i can think of a lot of reason feeling ashamed about needing med worrying about side effect forgetting about them etc but at the end of the day i can t say exactly why i just know i don t want to take my med at the same time i know i need them i know that without them i simple task like showering and doing dish feel impossible i ll fall behind on my schoolwork isolated myself and sleep hour a day i know they work for me and that i ve felt much better when i wa taking them regularly but dang it i just don t want to take them one day i just ignored my alarm to take them and then i ve kept doing it now i take them so sporadically that they can t be doing much they re an ssri and mood stabilizer so they need to build up in your system and such part of me think maybe i just hate the daily reminder that i m not ok like i think that maybe if i ignore it for long enough i ll forget that i feel that way but even knowing that may be a part of it it doesn t feel like that s all there is to it and i don t know what to do about it mostly i m just wondering if anyone else feel like this too and if you do do you know why you feel that way and what may have helped you get back on track with taking them regularly i ve talked to my therapist and friend but i haven t been able to really figure out the full reason i feel this way or how to get back to taking them regularly if you ve dealt with this before or think you may understand why this resistance to taking med is happening i d appreciate hearing some potential reason or way to improve this of course everyone s mental health is unique so i may not relate to someone else s reason but i would still really appreciate hearing any potential one so i can understand my feeling about this a bit better

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 I understand that you're feeling conflicted about taking your medication, and it's causing a lot of distress for you. It's important to remember that you're not alone in experiencing these feelings. Many people struggle with the same issues when it comes to adhering to their treatment plans.

One possible reason for your resistance could be the fear of side effects or how others perceive you. These concerns are valid, but it's essential to weigh them against the benefits of the medication. Remember, the goal is to improve your mental health and well-being. Additionally, most side effects are manageable with proper communication with your healthcare provider.

Another factor to consider is the daily reminder that you're not okay. This feeling can be challenging to confront, but it's crucial to recognize that acknowledging your struggles doesn't make you weak. In fact, by seeking help and taking steps towards recovery, you're showing strength and resilience.

It's also worth exploring if there are any underlying beliefs or thoughts that contribute to your resistance. Sometimes, our minds create irrational or unhelpful narratives that hinder our progress. Reflecting on these thoughts and questioning their validity can help challenge and reframe them in a more positive light.

Lastly, it's essential to communicate openly with your therapist about your concerns and difficulties. They can provide valuable insights, guidance, and support tailored specifically to your situation. Together, you can work towards finding effective strategies to overcome this resistance and establish a consistent medication routine.

Remember, everyone's journey is unique, and what works for one person may not work for another. Be patient with yourself and allow room for trial and error as you navigate this process. You deserve to live a fulfilling life, and with the right support and tools, you can regain control over your mental health.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

no one will read this but there would be occasion i took benzodiazepine and alcohol together and had no memory for example mg ativan and a beer or beer and three ativan or beer and ativan i haven t done that in awhile issue is i am having extreme anxiety that i have ruined my brain chemical somehow like very bad and now i ve convinced myself i ve ruined my brain and i m going to be anxious forever

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It's important to acknowledge the concerns you have about your brain chemistry and anxiety. While it can be distressing to experience such intense anxiety, there are steps you can take to manage it.

Firstly, it's crucial to understand that your brain is incredibly resilient and has the ability to recover from various challenges. The fact that you're able to function and engage with others is a testament to its resilience.

Additionally, it's essential to address the misconception that one instance of substance use automatically ruins brain chemistry. Brain chemistry is influenced by numerous factors, including genetics, environment, and lifestyle choices. One occasion of substance use, even if it involved both alcohol and benzodiazepines, does not necessarily mean your brain has been irreparably damaged.

That being said, it's understandable that you may still feel anxious about this. In situations like these, it can be helpful to challenge negative thoughts by asking yourself if there is any concrete evidence supporting them. Often, our worries are based on assumptions rather than facts.

Furthermore, consider exploring healthy coping mechanisms for managing anxiety. This could include practicing relaxation techniques like deep breathing exercises, mindfulness meditation, or engaging in activities that bring you joy and relaxation. Regular exercise, maintaining a balanced diet, and getting enough sleep can also contribute to overall mental well-being.

Remember, seeking support from trusted friends, family members, or a mental health professional can provide valuable guidance and reassurance during times of heightened anxiety. They can offer personalized strategies to help you navigate through this difficult period.

Please keep in mind that while I am here to provide guidance and suggestions, it's always beneficial to consult with a mental health expert who can assess your specific situation and offer tailored advice.

Many people struggle with depression and self-hatred, and it can be incredibly difficult to navigate through these emotions on your own. While I can't provide professional help, I can offer some guidance and support based on my own experiences and what has helped others.

One thing to keep in mind is that self-hatred is often a result of negative self-talk. When we're feeling down, it's easy to believe the worst things about ourselves. However, try to challenge those negative thoughts by focusing on your positive qualities. Remind yourself of times when you've succeeded or made a positive impact on someone else's life.  I can understand how difficult it must be for you to navigate through these emotional challenges. It takes a lot of courage to reach out and share your feelings. While I'm not a mental health expert, I can offer some guidance and suggestions based on my own experiences and understanding.

Firstly, it's important to acknowledge that you're not alone in feeling this way. Many people struggle with similar emotions and fears. It's completely normal to crave emotional safety and connection, especially if you've grown up in an environment where intimacy was lacking.

Building emotional intimacy can take time and effort. It starts with understanding and accepting yourself for who you are. Embrace your unique qualities, including your rebellious streak, as they are a part of what makes you special. Remember that you have grown and changed over the years, and while there may be moments where you feel like causing inconvenience, it doesn't define your entire character.

When it comes to relationships, try not to judge too quickly. Everyone has their own insecurities and fears, and it's essential to give others the benefit of the doubt. Focus on getting to know someone on a deeper level, beyond just their appearance or preconceived notions. Engage in meaningful conversations, share your interests, and build a connection based on mutual respect and understanding.

It's also important to address the fear of judgment. While it's natural to worry about how others perceive us, remember that true friends and potential partners will accept you for who you are. Embrace your individuality and let your personality shine through. Surround yourself with people who appreciate you for the person you are, rather than those who focus solely on external factors like race or appearance.

Additionally, therapy can be a valuable resource for exploring these issues further. A trained therapist can provide a safe and non-judgmental space for you to delve into your childhood experiences, work through past traumas, and develop healthier coping mechanisms. They can offer personalized strategies to help you overcome your fears and build stronger relationships.

Remember, healing and personal growth take time. Be patient with yourself as you navigate this journey. Surround yourself with supportive friends, engage in activities that bring you joy, and practice self-care. You deserve to feel emotionally safe and connected, and with time and effort, you can create the life you desire.

i had a meeting that i knew wa going to go well but i couldn t control my breathing and my heart rate wa insane i wa filling time with some paperwork but i couldn t focus i tried box breathing and it didn t work forgot to try grounding technique but will moving forward just to mention this pre event anxiety is normal a a kid going to birthday party made me anxious happens all the time still but this is the first time i just couldn t breathe this wa such a worrying experience i have something to actually worry about tomorrow and i hope it doesn t go the same way i honestly don t think it will because my body seems to react to adrenaline differently based on specific situation i am stressed thinking about it now or stressed because i m stressed maybe a soon a i sat down in that meeting i wa completely fine thought it might have been a combination of walking too fast and then my body not recovering from a weird breathing pattern but then i wa walking the same way later completely fine i ve been sighing all day which is what i tend to do when i am stressed i am trying to get help but yeah thing aren t moving along very well i m going to make an appointment with my therapist a soon a possible we are working together on an unrelated issue but i think we ll benefit from talking about it also worried about an upcoming wisdom teeth surgery anyway going to go cry so i can get some of this out of my system

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 I'm here for you, and I understand how overwhelming it can be to experience such intense anxiety symptoms. It's important to remember that anxiety is a normal response, but when it becomes difficult to manage, it can feel debilitating. You mentioned that you've been feeling stressed all day, and it seems like your body is reacting strongly to certain situations. This is something we can explore together.

Firstly, let's talk about the breathing exercises you tried during your meeting. Box breathing, also known as diaphragmatic breathing, is an effective technique for managing anxiety. However, it's essential to ensure that you're practicing it correctly. If you're unsure, I can guide you through the process step by step. Additionally, it might be helpful to try different breathing exercises to find what works best for you.

Regarding your heart rate, it's common for anxiety to cause an increase in heart rate. However, if it becomes too intense and affects your ability to function, there are other strategies we can explore. One approach is progressive muscle relaxation, where you tense and release different muscle groups to promote relaxation throughout your body. Another technique is mindfulness meditation, which involves focusing your attention on the present moment without judgment.

You mentioned that you've been sighing all day, and that's a common physical manifestation of stress. It's important to identify the underlying causes of your sighing and explore ways to address them. For example, if you're feeling overwhelmed, it could be helpful to break tasks into smaller, more manageable steps. Additionally, incorporating regular exercise into your routine can help reduce stress levels.

Regarding your upcoming wisdom teeth surgery, it's natural to feel anxious about any medical procedure. Preparing yourself by gathering information about the process, understanding what to expect, and discussing any concerns with your dentist can help alleviate some of the anxiety. Additionally, practicing relaxation techniques leading up to the surgery may also be beneficial.

Lastly, I encourage you to continue seeking support from your therapist. They can provide you with personalized guidance and strategies to manage your anxiety effectively. Remember, therapy is a collaborative process, and by working together, we can make progress towards reducing the impact of anxiety on your daily life.

Please take care of yourself, and remember that you're not alone in this journey. I'm here to support you every step of the way.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

self explanatory title i can make it through the day when distracted with a busy day at work or surrounded by friend but a soon a i m alone or i have a minute to think i realise how deeply unhappy i am in almost every aspect of my life i don t want to die i know there s thing to live for like family friend travelling new career potential love and child and maybe being one day happy but every day i wake up and struggle i feel little part of my health and sanity being chiseled off one by one and i just don t know how long i can do this for before i just give up

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 I understand how difficult it is to feel this way, and I want you to know that you're not alone. It takes a lot of courage to reach out and share your feelings. While I'm not a mental health expert, I can offer some suggestions that might help.

Firstly, it's important to acknowledge the emotions you're experiencing. It's okay to feel unhappy, and it's okay to seek support. Remember, reaching out is a sign of strength, not weakness.

One strategy that may be helpful is to focus on the present moment. When negative thoughts arise, try to redirect your attention to something positive or enjoyable in your immediate surroundings. This could be as simple as appreciating the weather, listening to music, or engaging in a hobby. Grounding techniques like deep breathing exercises or mindfulness meditation can also help bring your attention back to the present.

Additionally, consider reaching out to someone you trust, such as a close friend or family member. Sharing your feelings with someone who cares about you can provide comfort and perspective. Sometimes, just talking things through can help alleviate some of the burden you're carrying.

It's also important to take care of your physical health. Engaging in regular exercise, eating nutritious meals, and getting enough sleep can have a positive impact on your overall well-being. Physical activity releases endorphins, which are natural mood boosters.

Lastly, please remember that seeking professional help from a mental health expert can be beneficial. They are trained to provide guidance and support tailored to your specific needs. If you're unsure where to find a mental health professional, you can start by asking your primary care physician for a referral.

Please take care of yourself and know that there is hope for a brighter future.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]
