[Question]
hi everyone it s my first time posting on this forum i m really in a bad spot wondering if my anxiety ruined my situationship and would love to talk it through with someone if anyone could message me i d really appreciate it here s a bit more color on the situation we were good friend started talking in december hooked up beginning of february got into a disagreement the next weekend at a bar because this girl who he had hooked up with previously wa all over him and it made me visibly very uncomfortable we spend the next week talking every day but not seeing each other i definitely try to initiate a few hangout so doe he but le so and it didn t really work i know he s also talking to other girl a well but continues to tell me that he really like me and just want to keep getting to know me better last saturday we hook up he again tell me how much he like me and that he doesnt want to play game thursday i ask him over snapchat if he want to meet up for st paddy and he doesnt answer we end up at the same bar i make a comment saying ohh i thought you said no game just teasing he get upset and think i m trying to have a feeling talk with him at a bar while he s drunk we flush it out over text the next day and i ask him if he want to hang out this weekend he say we ll see and that he ha some plan already we end up bumping into each other again on saturday this time we talk the whole afternoon but i can tell he s le flirty more withdrawn he s going to a concert so he leaf i tell him later we re all going out to this bar he like and he heart the message this morning i snap him and ask how the concert wa no response obviously i need to leave this man alone at least for a little bit but i feel like back the first time we hooked up he wa so so into me then i ruined it by being jealous at the bar and by continuing to only pursue him i got complete tunnel vision i should have just left him alone and maybe he would have come to me but now i ve put so much pressure on the situation it doesn t help that my roommate who is his friend tell me constantly how much he doesn t actually like me and that he s just a player

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 I'm sorry to hear that you're feeling this way. It sounds like you've been through a lot with this guy, and the situation has caused a lot of anxiety for you. It's understandable that you're questioning if your anxiety ruined the potential for something more.

Anxiety can definitely impact our ability to navigate relationships, especially when it comes to interpreting someone's actions or intentions. It's important to remember that people are complex, and their behavior can be influenced by various factors. Sometimes, our own insecurities and fears can cloud our judgment and make us misinterpret situations.

In your case, it seems like your anxiety led you to believe that the girl from the bar was a threat to your relationship with this guy. However, it's essential to consider that attraction and chemistry can fluctuate, and it doesn't necessarily mean the end of a connection. Additionally, it's crucial to communicate openly with your partner about your feelings and concerns rather than making assumptions.

It's also worth mentioning that your roommate's perspective might be influenced by her own biases and experiences. Remember, everyone has different opinions, and it's essential to focus on how you feel and what you truly believe. Trusting your instincts and giving yourself time to reflect on the situation can help you gain clarity.

While I understand that you're seeking guidance, it's important to remember that I'm not a mental health professional. However, I encourage you to consider reaching out to a licensed therapist who can provide personalized support and guidance tailored to your specific needs. They can help you explore the root causes of your anxiety, develop coping strategies, and provide valuable insights into navigating relationships.

Take care of yourself, and remember that you deserve happiness and fulfillment.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 i'm really sorry to hear that you're feeling this way. It takes a lot of courage to reach out and share your thoughts, so I commend you for that. I want you to know that there is hope and support available to you.

It's important to remember that you are not alone in feeling this way. Many people struggle with similar emotions, and it's not uncommon to feel overwhelmed by negative thoughts. While I can't provide professional help, I can offer some guidance and suggestions based on my own experiences and knowledge.

Firstly, it's crucial to acknowledge the validity of your feelings. Just because others may have had it worse doesn't diminish the pain you're experiencing. Your emotions are real, and they matter. It's essential to be kind to yourself and understand that your feelings are valid.

One helpful strategy is to challenge negative thoughts. When we're in a low place, our minds tend to focus on the worst aspects of our lives. Try to identify these negative patterns and question their validity. Ask yourself if there is evidence to support these thoughts or if they are simply assumptions. Often, we realize that our negative beliefs are not grounded in reality.

Additionally, finding healthy coping mechanisms can make a significant difference. Engaging in activities that bring you joy, even if it feels difficult at first, can help shift your focus away from negativity. This could include hobbies, exercise, spending time in nature, or connecting with loved ones. Remember, small steps forward are still progress.

If you're comfortable, consider reaching out to someone you trust, such as a close friend or family member. Sharing your feelings with someone who cares about you can provide much-needed support and understanding. Sometimes, just talking to someone can make a world of difference.

Lastly, please remember that seeking professional help from a mental health expert can be incredibly beneficial. They have the expertise and tools to guide you through this difficult time. If you're unsure where to start, you can research local resources or speak with your primary care physician, who can provide recommendations.

Please take care of yourself and know that there is hope for a brighter future. You deserve happiness and support, and I believe in your strength to overcome this challenging period.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 I'm really glad to hear that you've decided to reach out for support, even if it's just for now. It takes a lot of courage to share your feelings and experiences, so I commend you for that.

Firstly, I want to assure you that you're not alone in this. Many people struggle with depression, and it can be incredibly difficult to navigate through life when you're feeling this way. While I'm not a mental health expert, I can offer some guidance and suggestions based on my own experiences and knowledge.

It's important to remember that seeking help is a positive step towards healing. There are various resources available to you, such as hotlines, online communities, and even local support groups. These resources can provide you with the emotional support and understanding that you may be seeking.

Additionally, finding healthy coping mechanisms can make a significant difference in managing your symptoms. Engaging in activities that bring you joy, like hobbies or spending time in nature, can help improve your mood. Building a strong support system is crucial as well. While it may feel like you don't have many friends or family members, there are still people who care about you. Reach out to them and let them know what you're going through. Sometimes, just having someone to talk to can make a world of difference.

Remember, recovery takes time, and it's okay to have setbacks along the way. Be patient with yourself and celebrate even the smallest victories. You deserve happiness and peace, and with the right support and tools, you can find them.

i m not sure if i have anxiety or adhd or im just introverted and procrastinating lol i started biting my nail since i wa a kid i tried hard to get rid of this habit but it not something i can control i put on nail polish usually but once it fall ill start biting them or fixing them with nail clipper a little bit of unsmoothness on my nail will bother me a lot and ill just sit there and keep fixing it for hour straight instead of doing any work literally every 0 min i would find somewhere bothering me on my nail i also overthink a lot it might be influenced by my mom who kept telling me that others might think negatively about me bc of any barely noticeable detail about what i do how i look so now i will just replay some scenario in my head hundred of time feel bad about myself and had to take deep breath say to myself it ok out loud or make some sudden noise to make my mind jump out of that vicious loop recently i feel that my attention span is getting even shorter i will sit down for work and get distracted after min and start watching youtube video for hour i notice myself doing that and i would think maybe i should go back to work but the other part of my mind is like numb and fail to take any action to the point that im only able to focus for a long time under pressure like a day before meeting or exam idk if it is just bad work ethic procrastination introversion or i should get a check up for anxiety adhd like i heard other ppl relate to me on point amp so idk if it just some common problem that i can just work it out either way can anyone give me any advice on whether to get a diagnosis or smth i could do on my own to mitigate these behavior thanks

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 I understand that you're feeling overwhelmed and unsure about your mental health. It's important to remember that I'm not a professional, but I can offer some suggestions based on what you've shared.

Firstly, it's common for people to bite their nails, especially when they're stressed or anxious. Nail-biting is often an unconscious habit that can be difficult to control. One technique that might help is practicing mindfulness. When you notice yourself biting your nails, try to pause, take a deep breath, and bring your attention back to the present moment. Remind yourself that you're safe and there's no need to engage in this behavior.

Regarding your overthinking tendencies, it's understandable that you're concerned about how others perceive you. However, it's essential to remember that most people are too busy with their own lives to pay much attention to small details or judge you harshly. Remind yourself of your strengths and positive qualities, and focus on self-acceptance rather than seeking external validation.

Your short attention span and difficulty focusing are also common challenges. It's important to create an environment that supports concentration, such as minimizing distractions, organizing your workspace, and breaking tasks into smaller, manageable chunks. Additionally, incorporating regular breaks can help maintain focus and prevent burnout.

While I can't diagnose you, it might be beneficial for you to seek professional help from a mental health expert who can provide a proper evaluation. They can assess your symptoms, discuss potential treatment options, and guide you through evidence-based interventions. Remember, reaching out for support is a sign of strength, and there are resources available to assist you on your journey towards improved well-being.

i started therapy for the panic attack that i ve been having it s definitely helped and my therapist recommended that i d benefit from having a medication to take a needed he thought this would help me continue to push the boundary that trigger the panic and that those exposure would help resolve thing he s a sole practitioner and a lcsw i made the appointment with my regular doctor who told me that even with the therapist recommendation he wouldn t write a prescription for a controlled substance and i needed to see a psychiatrist i didn t know these drug were controlled another month pass by while i wait for the psychiatrist appointment hour and 0 later they tell me the same thing they will only prescribe something that i take every day i don t want to take daily medication and my therapist seems to think that s not the best choice i m not a doctor and am just trying to do the best i can to get better am i asking for something crazy is there a medication that isn t controlled that i could ask for or reference i m trying really hard to get out of my comfort zone and get thing back to normal both for me and for my family i feel like a drug seeker now and am embarrassed to go see another psychiatrist i m not sure what i m supposed to do next

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 I understand how frustrating and disheartening this experience has been for you. It's important to remember that each person's journey is unique, and what works for one may not work for another. While I'm not a mental health professional, I can offer some suggestions and guidance.

1. Research: Take some time to research different medications commonly used for panic attacks. Understanding the potential benefits and side effects of various options can help you have an informed conversation with a healthcare provider.

2. Communication: When you meet with a psychiatrist, make sure to openly communicate your concerns, goals, and preferences. Explain that you're looking for a short-term solution rather than a daily medication. Emphasize that you're willing to work collaboratively with them to find the best course of treatment.

3. Consultation: If possible, seek a second opinion from another psychiatrist. Sometimes, different professionals may have different perspectives and approaches. A fresh pair of eyes and ears might lead to a different outcome.

4. Alternative Therapies: Explore alternative therapeutic options that complement your therapy sessions. Techniques such as deep breathing exercises, mindfulness, grounding techniques, and relaxation exercises can all help manage panic attacks.

5. Support System: Lean on your support system - friends, family, or even online communities. Sharing your experiences and feelings with others who have gone through similar situations can provide validation, encouragement, and practical advice.

Remember, finding the right medication and dosage often involves trial and error. It's essential to be patient with yourself throughout this process. Keep advocating for your well-being, and don't give up hope. You deserve to live a life free from panic attacks, and with time and persistence, you will find the support and treatment that works best for you.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[Question]
i m not a big fan of sharing overly personal stuff online so i ll just say that i ll have to take a moderately long plane ride soon a couple week from now i think and every day i have at least one mini panic attack worrying about it there are some minor complication that could happen to me on the flight but nothing particularly harmful or super bad in any sense i m mostly concerned about anxiety claustrophobia and the side effect of that while on the flight this is stressful and feel pointless a i know from past experience i never know how i ll feel until i m there or in this case in the anxiety inducing situation any advice

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It's completely understandable that you're feeling anxious about your upcoming flight. Anxiety and worry are common before traveling, especially when it involves flying. Here are a few suggestions that might help you manage your anxiety:

1. Preparation: Gathering information about your flight can provide a sense of control. Look up the airline, the route, and familiarize yourself with the safety procedures. This knowledge can help alleviate some uncertainty.

2. Distraction techniques: Engaging in activities during the flight can divert your attention from anxious thoughts. Consider bringing a book, listening to music, watching a movie, or doing puzzles. Finding something enjoyable or engaging can distract you from feeling anxious.

3. Deep breathing exercises: Practice deep breathing techniques to calm your body and mind. Take slow, deep breaths in through your nose, hold for a few seconds, and then exhale slowly through your mouth. This technique can help regulate your breathing and reduce feelings of panic.

4. Grounding techniques: When you start feeling overwhelmed, grounding techniques can bring you back to the present moment. Focus on your senses by describing what you see, hear, smell, taste, and touch. This exercise helps shift your attention away from anxious thoughts and into the immediate environment.

5. Positive self-talk: Challenge negative thoughts by replacing them with more realistic and positive statements. Remind yourself that millions of people fly safely every day, and you have successfully flown in the past. Emphasize your capabilities and resilience.

Remember, everyone experiences anxiety differently, so it's important to find coping strategies that work best for you. If your anxiety persists and significantly impacts your daily life, consider seeking professional help from a mental health expert who can provide personalized guidance and support.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

 I'm really sorry to hear that you're feeling this way. It sounds like you're going through a lot right now, both physically and mentally. It's important to remember that you're not alone in this, and there are people who care about you. While I can't solve all of your problems, I can offer some guidance and support.

Firstly, it's crucial to prioritize your self-care. You mentioned taking care of your dog and doing household chores, which is a great start. Additionally, consider incorporating activities that bring you joy or relaxation into your daily routine. This could be reading, listening to music, practicing mindfulness, or engaging in hobbies. Taking care of yourself can help improve your mood and overall well-being.

Regarding your employment status, it might be helpful to explore different job opportunities that align with your abilities and interests. While it can be challenging, don't be too hard on yourself. Remember that everyone faces setbacks at some point in their lives, and it doesn't define your worth as a person. You could also consider seeking assistance from employment agencies or career counselors who can provide guidance and resources to help you find suitable employment.

Additionally, reaching out to trusted friends or family members for emotional support can make a significant difference. Sometimes, just talking to someone who cares about us can provide comfort and perspective. If you're comfortable doing so, consider sharing your feelings with someone you trust. They may be able to offer insights or suggestions that you hadn't considered before.

Remember, healing takes time, and it's okay to seek professional help if needed. A mental health professional can provide you with personalized strategies and coping mechanisms to manage your emotions and challenges more effectively. They can also offer a safe space for you to express yourself without judgment.

Please know that there is hope for a brighter future, and you deserve happiness and fulfillment. Take things one step at a time, be kind to yourself, and remember that there is always light at the end of the tunnel.

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you've been experiencing a lot of distress due to excessive worrying and overthinking. This is causing disruptions in your daily life, even when you're trying to focus on other things. It's understandable that this is causing you a lot of frustration and anxiety.

While I'm not a mental health expert, I can offer some suggestions that may help you manage your symptoms. One technique that could be helpful is practicing mindfulness. Mindfulness involves bringing your attention to the present moment without judgment. When you notice yourself starting to worry or overthink, try to redirect your focus to the present moment. You can do this by paying attention to your senses, such as the feeling of the ground beneath your feet or the sounds around you.

Another strategy is challenging your anxious thoughts. Ask yourself if there is any evidence to support your worries. Often, our anxious thoughts are based on irrational fears rather than reality. By questioning the validity of these thoughts, you can begin to challenge their power over you.

Additionally, it might be beneficial for you to engage in activities that bring you joy and relaxation. Find hobbies or interests that distract you from your worries and provide a sense of fulfillment. Whether it's reading, painting, exercising, or spending time in nature, doing things that you enjoy can help shift your focus away from anxious thoughts.

Remember, everyone's experience with anxiety is unique, so what works for one person may not work for another. If your symptoms persist or worsen, it's important to seek professional help from a mental health expert who can provide personalized guidance and support.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[Question]
my anxiety is so bad right now i have been vomiting and have bad pain in my stomach and abdomen lot of sweating and extreme issue sleeping last night i didn t fall asleep until am and woke up at am in a complete panic eating is very difficult for me right now and i have a sense of impending doom constantly is there anything any of you do that help with this how can i bring this up with my doctor without being committed or something should i get a short supply of benzos to get through this time i just need some advice thank you

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 I'm really sorry to hear that you're going through such a difficult time with your anxiety. It sounds like it's causing a lot of physical symptoms and interfering with your daily life. I understand that finding relief is important for you right now.

While I'm not a medical professional, there are some strategies that people have found helpful in managing anxiety. One approach is deep breathing exercises, where you take slow, deep breaths in through your nose and out through your mouth. This can help activate your body's relaxation response and reduce feelings of panic.

Another technique is grounding yourself in the present moment. You can do this by focusing on your senses - notice the feeling of your feet on the ground, the sounds around you, or the texture of an object in your hand. Engaging your senses can help distract your mind from anxious thoughts and bring you back to the present.

Additionally, it might be beneficial to explore coping mechanisms such as journaling, practicing mindfulness, or engaging in activities that bring you joy and relaxation. These can provide a sense of release and help redirect your focus away from anxious thoughts.

Regarding your concern about discussing this with your doctor, it's important to remember that seeking help is a sign of strength, not weakness. When you're ready, I encourage you to have an open and honest conversation with your doctor about what you've been experiencing. They can provide guidance, support, and potentially recommend appropriate treatment options tailored to your needs.

Remember, everyone's journey is unique, so what works for one person may not work for another. It's essential to find the strategies and treatments that resonate with you personally. Take care of yourself, and know that there is hope for finding relief from anxiety.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

everytime she behaves distant because of her own issue that would be selfish hell she even told me she won t stop loving me even if she cant express it but my anxiety is still there the worst thing is that she doesn t want to speak about what s bothering her because she doesn t want to think about it which make me feel like it s me and then i feel like an asshole because i am not the center of the world so yeah long story short my abandonment issue are the worst thing right now i decided not to bother her with it because it s not fair but i don t know how to deal with it oh and those issue wouldn t be so bad if i weren t so anxious in general the general anxiety came with the practical part of my education but i don t know why because i am doing good i will be done with that in week and However, it seems like your anxiety has been increasing lately, particularly regarding your fear of dying and your girlfriend leaving you. These are valid concerns, but it's crucial to challenge the thoughts that fuel these anxieties. Remind yourself of the evidence that supports your stability and the love and commitment your girlfriend has shown you.

Additionally, it's understandable that your past experiences have shaped your anxiety. Reflecting on your childhood and problematic personality traits can provide valuable insights into the roots of your anxiety. However, it's essential to avoid blaming yourself or feeling like an asshole because of your anxiety. Remember, anxiety is a common human experience, and it's not your fault. Instead, focus on self-compassion and self-care. Engage in activities that bring you joy and relaxation, such as exercise, mindfulness, or hobbies.

Regarding your girlfriend's distant behavior, it's natural to feel concerned when someone we care about acts distant. However, it's crucial to remember that everyone has ups and downs, and it's not always about us. Encourage open communication with your girlfriend, expressing your feelings and concerns while being respectful and understanding. Validate her emotions and offer support, reminding her that you're there for her. By fostering a safe space for dialogue, you can work together to address any issues she may be facing.

In conclusion, managing anxiety takes time and patience. Be kind to yourself throughout this process, and remember that you're doing the best you can. Seek professional help if you feel it would be beneficial, as therapists can provide personalized strategies and support tailored to your specific needs. With self-care, open communication, and professional guidance, you can navigate your anxiety and nurture a healthy relationship.

[Question]
i ve been dealing with serious depression for the last 0 year one huge thing is the mental fatigue i m always feeling in my head making it hard to get up and do thing what have you done to help relieve that so thing are much easier to do and enjoy i m planning on switching job but the mental exhaustion is making so hard to go for it so any advice would be amazing

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It's great that you're reaching out for support. Dealing with serious depression can be incredibly challenging, especially when it affects your daily functioning. The mental fatigue you described is a common symptom of depression and can make even simple tasks feel overwhelming.

One strategy that may help relieve the mental exhaustion is breaking tasks down into smaller, more manageable steps. By focusing on one small task at a time, it can feel less daunting and more achievable. Celebrating each accomplishment, no matter how small, can also provide a sense of motivation and boost your self-confidence.

Additionally, incorporating self-care activities into your routine can make a significant difference. Engaging in activities that bring you joy and relaxation, such as hobbies, exercise, or spending time in nature, can help alleviate some of the mental fatigue. Prioritizing sleep, maintaining a healthy diet, and seeking social support from loved ones are also important factors in managing depression.

Regarding your job switch, I understand how difficult it can be to find the motivation and energy to make such a big change, especially when you're feeling mentally exhausted. It might be helpful to explore what specifically about your current job is draining your energy and enthusiasm. Reflecting on your values, interests, and long-term goals can guide you towards a career that aligns better with your passions and aspirations.

Remember, everyone's journey is unique, and what works for one person may not work for another. If you find that these strategies aren't providing enough relief, consider reaching out to a mental health professional who can offer personalized guidance and support tailored to your specific needs.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[Question]
i have irrational fear of a home invasion being attacked by a stranger for context even thing like elderly woman with cane walking behind me sends me into panic mode me and my fianc just bought our first home together after renting for year instead of me being able to rest after a long day of moving i am instead laying awake because the house is settling every 0 second and i keep thinking it s an intruder coming to kill me this ha been going on for two hour my heart keep pounding out of my chest randomly and i keep getting so frozen with fear that i hold my breath my mind is working overtime playing escape plan confrontation scenario on repeat so i can t relax this is so fucking irrational i hate it i ve been this way a long a i can remember but ugh i know why house creek i also know this home is older which is something i love about it during the day but i can not seem to think logically about this every pop creek and bang is sending me into panic mode and i don t have any remedy i m sick of being constantly on alert for no reason this is an extremely safe neighborhood and i should not need to be this worried over nothing some night are better than others but why do i even have to go through this at all i apologize for the rant but i am so exhausted and i just want to sleep but i keep getting snapped awake

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 I understand how overwhelming and exhausting it can be to experience such intense fear and anxiety, especially when you're trying to relax and rest. It's important to remember that these feelings are valid, but they don't align with reality. You've mentioned that you've had these fears for a long time, and it's understandable that they've become distressing.

One approach that might help is grounding yourself in the present moment. When you notice yourself getting caught up in anxious thoughts or scenarios, try focusing on your immediate surroundings. Pay attention to the details of your environment, like the texture of the floor beneath your feet, the sounds you hear, or the objects around you. This can help shift your focus away from anxious thoughts and bring you back to the present.

Additionally, practicing relaxation techniques such as deep breathing exercises, progressive muscle relaxation, or guided imagery can be helpful in reducing anxiety symptoms. These techniques can help calm your body and mind, allowing you to feel more relaxed and at ease.

It's also important to challenge the irrational thoughts that contribute to your anxiety. Ask yourself if there is any evidence to support these fears, and consider alternative explanations for the noises you hear in your home. Remind yourself that the likelihood of a home invasion is extremely low, and that you are safe in your own home.

While these suggestions may not eliminate your anxiety completely, they can provide you with tools to manage it more effectively. Remember, progress takes time and patience, so be kind to yourself throughout this process. If you find that your anxiety continues to significantly impact your daily life, it may be beneficial to seek professional help from a mental health expert who can provide personalized guidance and support.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

i have suffered with shortness of breath due to anxiety ever since i wa diagnosed with gad generalized anxiety disorder about year ago doe anyone else have this it just feel like i will stop breathing doe anyone have any coping mechanism around this a it s really horrible a well a shortness of breath i also feel shaky and tingly and i have no idea how to calm down when i have these episode

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 I understand how distressing it can be to experience shortness of breath, especially when it's related to anxiety. It's important to remember that you're not alone in this, as many individuals with GAD also struggle with similar symptoms. While I can't provide a diagnosis or treatment plan, I can offer some coping strategies that may help manage your anxiety-related shortness of breath.

1. Deep breathing exercises: Practice deep breathing techniques, such as diaphragmatic breathing or box breathing, to help regulate your breath. These exercises can help slow down your breathing and promote relaxation.

2. Progressive muscle relaxation: Engage in progressive muscle relaxation exercises, where you systematically tense and relax different muscle groups in your body. This technique can help release tension and promote a sense of calmness.

3. Grounding techniques: When you feel overwhelmed by anxiety, grounding techniques can help bring your focus back to the present moment. Try engaging your senses by focusing on things around you, like the texture of an object or the sound of birds chirping.

4. Self-care activities: Prioritize self-care activities that promote relaxation and stress reduction. This could include engaging in hobbies, practicing mindfulness or meditation, getting regular exercise, maintaining a healthy diet, and ensuring adequate sleep.

5. Seek support: Consider reaching out to a mental health professional who can provide personalized guidance and support. They can work with you to develop coping mechanisms tailored to your specific needs.

Remember, these coping strategies may not eliminate your symptoms entirely, but they can serve as tools to help manage your anxiety-related shortness of breath. Take it one step at a time, be patient with yourself, and remember that progress takes time.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It's tough to hear that you're feeling this way. It sounds like you're dealing with a lot of difficult emotions and situations. I want you to know that there is hope and support available to you.

Firstly, it's important to acknowledge the courage it takes to reach out and share your feelings. You're not alone in this, and there are people who care about your well-being. While I'm not a mental health expert, I can offer some suggestions that might be helpful.

1. Seeking professional help: Consider reaching out to a mental health professional who can provide guidance and support tailored to your specific needs. They can help you explore underlying causes of your depression and anxiety, develop coping strategies, and provide a safe space for you to express your emotions.

2. Building a support network: Surrounding yourself with supportive individuals can make a significant difference. While it may feel challenging to make new friends, joining local community groups, hobbies, or volunteering activities could provide opportunities to meet like-minded people. Engaging in activities you enjoy can also boost your mood and self-confidence.

3. Self-care practices: Taking care of yourself is crucial. Focus on incorporating self-care activities into your daily routine, such as exercise, getting enough sleep, eating nutritious meals, and engaging in activities that bring you joy. Additionally, practicing mindfulness techniques, such as deep breathing exercises or meditation, can help manage stress and anxiety.

4. Setting realistic goals: Breaking down overwhelming tasks into smaller, achievable goals can make them feel more manageable. Celebrate even the smallest victories along the way, as every step forward counts.

Remember, healing takes time, and progress may be slow. Be patient and kind to yourself throughout this journey. You deserve happiness and fulfillment, and with the right support, things can get better.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

i m not sure if this is the right subreddit to go to but i don t know where else to go my spouse ha struggled with severe depression his whole life it is genetic his dad wa the same any amount of pressure make him worse he constantly feel a though life is not worth living and he s a lost cause he will never feel okay and just want the pain to go away we have a baby coming any day now and i wa worried that pressure wa gon na send him over the edge we have been talking about having him voluntarily go to a psych ward and see if they can help kinda a a last ditch effort before i just give him permission to end it today he talked to his counselor about going to one in a few week after the baby wa here and they came and picked him up an hour later he is pissed doesn t want to be there which i understand is normal he feel completely betrayed by his councellor and never want to go back i m worried that now he is going to pretend like he is fine just to get out the point of this is to get help why won t he just take it i m scared the mental hospital won t help at all i just need you guy who have been there before to be honest with me did it help what thing helped and what made it worse if it doe help or when he come back home what are some thing i can do to continue the healing process or just make his life easier anything else you feel to share please do i hate not knowing thing and this is really killing me right now

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 I'm really sorry for the distress you're experiencing. It's understandable that you're concerned about your spouse's well-being and the impact of the baby's birth on his mental health. While I'm not a mental health professional, I can offer some guidance based on my understanding of depression.

Firstly, it's important to remember that everyone's experience with mental health is unique, so what works for one person may not work for another. However, there are some general strategies that have been found helpful in managing depression.

One approach is therapy, which can provide a safe space for your spouse to explore his feelings, thoughts, and behaviors. Cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) is a common type of therapy used for depression, focusing on identifying negative thought patterns and developing healthier coping mechanisms. Additionally, interpersonal therapy (IPT) can help improve relationships and social support, which can positively impact mental health.

In addition to therapy, medication can be considered as an option. Antidepressant medications can help regulate brain chemistry and alleviate symptoms of depression. However, it's crucial to consult with a healthcare professional who can evaluate the potential benefits and risks of medication for your spouse's specific situation.

It's also essential to create a supportive environment at home. Encourage open communication, where your spouse feels comfortable expressing his emotions without judgment. Offer practical assistance, such as helping with daily tasks, to reduce stress and burden. Engage in activities that bring joy and fulfillment to both of you, fostering a sense of connection and happiness.

Remember, healing takes time, and progress may not always be linear. Be patient with your spouse and yourself throughout this journey. Celebrate small victories and acknowledge the efforts put into improving mental health.

While I'm not a mental health expert, I hope these suggestions provide some guidance and support. If you have any further questions or concerns, please don't hesitate to reach out.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[Question]
i m currently taking 0mg effexor xr for anxiety and depression i ve also taken lexapro 0mg for year and zoloft 00mg for a year both had similar effect barely put a dent in my anxiety and really helped with the severe symptom of depression but it s still there my anxiety is still bad particularly my physical symptom i always feel on edge and nervous i can always feel my heart pounding hard not fast regardless of my mental state and it s the most debilitating symptom i feel i can never relax and never truly enjoy myself because of how anxious i feel i take propranolol 0mg twice a day and is the only thing that help a little with the physical symptom but they re still problematic i have tried meditation breathing exercise exercise i have read a multitude of book on cognitive behavioral therapy acceptance and commitment therapy and mindfulness no exercise in the book ha helped with the symptom whatsoever i should also mention i have had test for my thyroid adrenal any gi or diet issue antibody etc and i m sure i can rule out physical cause is anyone else in a similar boat to me and found buspirone helped if no ha anything helped you thanks

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 I understand how challenging it can be to manage anxiety symptoms, especially when they're impacting your daily life. It's important to remember that everyone's experience with anxiety is unique, and what works for one person may not work for another. However, there are some strategies that you might find helpful.

Firstly, it's great that you've been proactive in seeking support and trying different approaches. Anxiety can be treated effectively with a combination of therapy and medication. While I'm not a mental health professional, I can offer some suggestions based on common treatments for anxiety.

One approach you mentioned is cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT). CBT focuses on identifying and challenging negative thought patterns that contribute to anxiety. It also helps develop coping skills and strategies to manage anxious feelings. You mentioned reading books on CBT, which is a good start. However, it's essential to work with a qualified therapist who can guide you through the process and tailor the treatment to your specific needs.

Another therapy you mentioned is acceptance and commitment therapy (ACT). ACT helps individuals accept their anxious thoughts and feelings without judgment while committing to actions aligned with their values. This approach aims to reduce the impact of anxiety on your life by focusing on what truly matters to you. Again, working with a trained therapist would be beneficial in implementing this approach effectively.

In addition to therapy, medication can be an option worth discussing with a healthcare professional. Buspirone, which you mentioned, is a common medication used for anxiety. It works differently from other anti-anxiety medications and has fewer side effects. However, it's crucial to consult with a psychiatrist who can evaluate your symptoms and determine if medication is appropriate for you.

Additionally, self-care practices such as regular exercise, maintaining a healthy diet, getting enough sleep, and practicing relaxation techniques like deep breathing or progressive muscle relaxation can be beneficial. These activities help reduce stress levels and promote overall well-being.

Remember, finding the right combination of treatments may take time and patience. It's important to keep an open mind and be willing to try different approaches. If you haven't already, consider reaching out to a mental health professional who can provide personalized guidance and support. They can help you navigate through this journey and provide the assistance you need.

Please know that you're not alone in experiencing anxiety, and there is hope for improvement. With the right support and strategies, it's possible to manage your symptoms and regain control over your life.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[Question]
so i have a mild stutter and i just had an epiphany i ve been letting my stutter control me but i found something amazing out i let my stutter define who i wa a a person instead of an aspect of myself it s so bad that when my parent talk to me like a normal person i d think to myself wow they act like i m normal despite my stutter they see past that and when i would work people would see my name tag and say oh i have a son named my name and i would think he probably doesn t stutter tho i let this define who i wa a a person and i let it really get to me i wa looking at old reddit post from other people asking how people view stutter and most people said they didn t care at all and even found it interesting some even said it wa hot cute made joke sound more natural and a a result more funny not like they found the stutter funny tho and one even said they were turned on by it and someone said something that stuck out to me they pretty much said how you perceive yourself is how others will so if i see myself a weird and anxious i will act that way and be perceived in that way but if i see myself a confident and charismatic and just act like my stutter doesn t bother me and even joke about it then others will perceive me a such this blew my mind a i thought everyone didn t pick up on my stutter at first and just thought i wa super weird but it s just me convincing myself of that so even tho this clicked i still can t just flick the switch off so how do i actually become confident with my stutter it s very mild and is fueled by anxiety so if i can get rid of my anxiety it ll in my opinion make me sound more charismatic and confident so i really wan na figure out how to just own it how do i do this

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It's great that you've had this realization and are ready to take control of how you perceive yourself. It can be challenging to let go of long-held beliefs about ourselves, but with time and practice, it is possible to develop confidence and own your stutter.

One important step is to challenge the negative thoughts and beliefs you have about yourself. When you catch yourself thinking negatively, try to question those thoughts. Ask yourself if there is any evidence to support them or if they are just assumptions. Remind yourself of your strengths and accomplishments, both related to your stutter and unrelated. Focus on the aspects of your personality that make you unique and valuable, rather than letting your stutter define you.

Additionally, consider seeking support from a speech therapist or joining a stuttering support group. These resources can provide you with tools and strategies to manage your anxiety and improve your communication skills. They can also offer a sense of community where you can connect with others who share similar experiences.

Remember, building confidence takes time and patience. Be kind to yourself throughout this process and celebrate even the smallest victories. You deserve to feel confident and charismatic, stutter and all.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

so i ve struggled w executive dysfunction for 9 year throughout my year of college there wa not one assignment that i did not do the night before it wa due i studied late ate terribly amp went thru a terrible depression a year after graduating i still have a really hard time doing thing in general i stall before i do anything at all amp it oftentimes lead to me not doing the thing at all also i kind of live my entire life on pause only taking care of myself when i have something planned or to look forward to i left my job that i wa insanely good at bc the commitment amp longevity terrified me why can t i function amp what ha helped u work thru these feeling

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 I can understand how challenging it must be for you to deal with executive dysfunction and the struggles that come with it. It's important to remember that you're not alone in this, and there are steps you can take to manage your symptoms.

One strategy that might help is breaking tasks down into smaller, more manageable chunks. When everything feels overwhelming, try focusing on one small task at a time. Celebrate each accomplishment, no matter how small, as it can provide motivation to keep going.

Additionally, creating a routine or schedule can be beneficial. Having a structured plan can give you a sense of direction and purpose. Prioritize your tasks and allocate specific times for each one. This can help reduce procrastination and increase productivity.

It's also crucial to take care of yourself both physically and mentally. Make sure to get enough sleep, eat nutritious meals, and engage in regular exercise. These self-care practices can have a positive impact on your overall well-being and cognitive function.

In terms of managing your depression, it's essential to seek professional help from a mental health expert. They can provide you with appropriate guidance and support tailored to your specific needs. Remember, reaching out for help is a sign of strength, and there are resources available to assist you on your journey towards healing.

Lastly, finding healthy coping mechanisms that work for you can make a significant difference. Engaging in activities you enjoy, such as hobbies, sports, or spending time with loved ones, can provide a much-needed distraction and boost your mood.

Please keep in mind that these suggestions are general and may not address all aspects of your situation. If you ever feel overwhelmed or need immediate assistance, don't hesitate to reach out to a mental health professional who can provide personalized guidance.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[Question]
i live at home and i love my parent but i m beginning to spiral after an incident month ago i ve been profoundly depressed and stressed out i wa renting but moved back home to save money while trying to get myself back in order especially because my med stopped working i m an only child and my parent have no friend so now that i m back home all they want to do is constantly talk to me i already have poor sleep a it is but it could be am and my dad will shake me awake to talk about a car or his work day or my mom will come in and talk to me about my finance or why i never talk to her about my mental health one time recently i had been woken up so abruptly i could feel my entire nervous system jolt like i had been struck by lighting even thinking about it make my entire body randomly hurt i never get to be alone anymore i try to get alone time but i never get it for more than a couple hour at an time bc of the sleep deprivation i hallucinate now i hear and see thing i honestly wish somthing would happen to me and it would just all end life s so stressful and the little thing aren t fun anymore i hate myself i hate everything i used to love nothing fun anymore what s the fucking point

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 I'm really sorry to hear that you're feeling this way. It sounds like you're going through a very difficult time, and I understand how overwhelming it can be to constantly feel stressed and depressed. It's important to remember that you're not alone in this, and there are people who care about you and want to support you.

Given the circumstances you've described, it's understandable that you're struggling with your mental health. The combination of the incident, the move back home, and the constant need for validation from your parents can take a toll on anyone. Additionally, the fact that your medication isn't working for you is making things even more challenging.

While I can't provide professional help, I can offer some suggestions that might be helpful. Firstly, it's crucial to prioritize self-care. This means taking care of your physical health by getting regular exercise, eating nutritious meals, and trying to establish a consistent sleep schedule. Engaging in activities that bring you joy and relaxation, even if they don't feel as fun anymore, can also be beneficial.

Additionally, setting boundaries with your parents is essential. While it's natural for them to worry about you, constantly talking to you can be draining. Communicate your needs and let them know when you need some alone time. They may not fully understand how their actions affect you, so having an open and honest conversation could help them become more aware of your struggles.

It's also important to seek professional help from a mental health expert. They can evaluate your situation more comprehensively and provide personalized guidance and treatment options. Remember, reaching out for help is a sign of strength, and there are resources available to support you on your journey towards healing.

Lastly, please remember that your feelings are valid, and it's okay to feel overwhelmed. Be patient with yourself as you navigate through this difficult period, and try to focus on the small moments of joy and peace that you can find amidst the chaos. You deserve happiness and fulfillment, and with time, support, and self-care, you can find your way back to a place where life feels meaningful again.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

well i caved i cut myself for the first time today it didn t really hurt but it didn t help either i still feel like shit i can t take it anymore i switched school this year and have yet to make a single friend every day i m on the outside of the group i know that i did something to warrant this problem but no one will tell me what i did am doing i just gave up trying to nudge my way into conversation and just sit there and listen so i don t look like a lonely loser although i guess i look like one anyway anyone have any advice i need social interaction to get out of my depression also looking for new friend won t work a everyone in the grade act like i don t exist so don t suggest that

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 I'm really sorry to hear that you're feeling this way. It takes a lot of courage to reach out for support, and I want you to know that I'm here for you. While I can't replace the guidance of a mental health professional, I can offer some suggestions that might help.

Firstly, it's important to remember that self-harm is never the answer. It may provide temporary relief, but it can lead to deeper emotional pain in the long run. If you ever find yourself in a moment where you feel like self-harming, please reach out to someone you trust or call a helpline. There are people who care about you and want to support you through this.

Regarding your social interactions, it can be challenging to make friends, especially when you're feeling down. Instead of trying to force your way into conversations, try focusing on finding common interests or activities that genuinely interest you. Joining clubs, sports teams, or participating in school events related to your hobbies can provide opportunities to connect with like-minded individuals. Remember, making friends takes time and patience. Don't give up on yourself.

Additionally, practicing self-compassion is crucial. Remind yourself that everyone has their own insecurities and struggles. You are not alone in feeling this way, even though it may seem like it sometimes. Treat yourself with kindness and understanding, just as you would a close friend. Celebrate your strengths and achievements, no matter how small they may seem.

Lastly, if you're comfortable doing so, consider opening up to someone you trust about what you're going through. Sometimes, sharing our feelings with someone who cares can provide a sense of relief and support.

Remember, I'm here for you, even if it's just to listen. Keep reaching out, and know that there is hope for a brighter future.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[Question]
hi all i m f i ve had very bad anxiety disorder since 0 0 when my uncle passed away the following year i started taking medication and while it help it s not a cure all both my parent passed under different circumstance in october and it s wrecked my emotion i try to do the best i can but sometimes it s just a mess i m out of town right now and i feel so outside of my comfort zone i know i m safe but my stomach is in knot and sorry tmi i haven t left the bathroom much doe anyone have any advice is there anything i can do to calm myself or center myself thank you in advance

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 I'm really sorry to hear that you're going through such a difficult time. It sounds like the recent loss of your parents has triggered a significant emotional response, and it's completely understandable that you're feeling overwhelmed. While I'm not a mental health professional, I can offer some suggestions that might help you cope with your anxiety.

1. Deep breathing exercises: When you feel anxious, try taking slow, deep breaths. Inhale deeply through your nose, hold your breath for a few seconds, and then exhale slowly through your mouth. This technique can help relax your body and calm your mind.

2. Grounding techniques: If you find yourself feeling disconnected or outside of your comfort zone, grounding techniques can be helpful. Focus on your senses by identifying five things you can see, four things you can touch, three things you can hear, two things you can smell, and one thing you can taste. This exercise brings your attention back to the present moment and helps anchor you in reality.

3. Self-care: It's important to prioritize self-care during times of heightened anxiety. Make sure you're getting enough rest, eating nutritious meals, and engaging in activities that bring you joy. Consider incorporating relaxation techniques into your daily routine, such as meditation, yoga, or listening to calming music.

4. Reach out for support: Remember that you don't have to face this alone. Lean on your support system, whether it's friends, family members, or a trusted confidant. Talking about your feelings and sharing your experiences can provide comfort and validation.

Please keep in mind that these suggestions are not meant to replace professional help but rather offer some guidance during challenging moments. If you ever feel overwhelmed or need additional support, please consider reaching out to a mental health professional who can provide personalized care.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 I'm really sorry to hear that you're feeling this way. It sounds like you're going through a difficult time in your life, and it's understandable that you're feeling overwhelmed and hopeless. You've shared a lot about your current situation, and it's clear that there are many factors contributing to your distress.

Firstly, I want to acknowledge the courage it takes to reach out and share your feelings. It's important to remember that you don't have to face this alone. While I'm not a mental health expert, I can offer some guidance and suggestions based on my own experiences and knowledge.

It's important to address the elephant in the room, which is your feelings for your best friend. It's natural to develop deep connections with people we spend a lot of time with, especially when we're emotionally vulnerable. However, it's crucial to communicate these feelings openly and honestly with the person involved. If you feel comfortable doing so, expressing your emotions to her could help clarify the situation and potentially strengthen your friendship.

Additionally, it seems like you're dealing with a lot of external stressors, such as failing your college class, strained relationships with family and friends, and accusations within your organization. These challenges can be incredibly draining and affect your mental well-being. It might be helpful to explore coping strategies to manage stress, such as practicing self-care, engaging in activities you enjoy, seeking support from trusted individuals, and setting realistic goals for yourself.

Furthermore, it's essential to focus on your own personal growth and development. Take some time to reflect on your values, passions, and aspirations. What truly makes you happy? What are your long-term goals? By gaining clarity about what matters most to you, you can start taking steps towards creating a fulfilling future.

Remember, healing takes time, and it's okay to seek professional help if you need it. A mental health therapist can provide you with the necessary tools and support to navigate through this challenging period in your life. They can offer personalized strategies to help you manage your emotions, develop healthy coping mechanisms, and work towards a brighter future.

Please know that there is hope, and things can get better. You deserve to live a fulfilling and meaningful life. Keep reaching out for support, and don't hesitate to ask for help when you need it.

hi idk if anyone will comment and thats okay i just need to talk or something since i m just so tired of my thought and just this worthless feeling i have all the time dealing with depression is no joke and being in a small town suck more since there not many resource or help for me i ve gotten a little help here and there but have just fallen back to being in my room isolating myself i have suicidal thought quite often and worry i might act on them not soon mind you just scared of myself i think of plan on how i could do it i ve written letter directed towards family member and friend before though i keep them to myself i ve self harmed before but haven t for quite sometime though i worry i may resort to that again i really just want help but i have no idea how i can even get it anyhow i thank anyone for reading if you did i don t have a lot of hope left but i guess i m still alive so yeah

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 I'm really sorry to hear that you're feeling this way. It takes a lot of courage to reach out and share your struggles, so I commend you for doing so. Dealing with depression can be incredibly challenging, especially when resources are limited. It's important to remember that there is hope and help available, even if it may not always feel like it.

Firstly, I want to emphasize that you don't have to face this alone. While I'm not a mental health professional, there are people who can provide the guidance and support you need. Consider reaching out to a trusted friend or family member who can offer a listening ear and emotional support. Sometimes, just having someone to talk to can make a significant difference.

Additionally, it might be helpful to explore local resources in your area. There could be support groups, community centers, or helplines that provide assistance to individuals experiencing mental health difficulties. These resources can provide valuable information, coping strategies, and a sense of community.

Regarding your suicidal thoughts, it's crucial to take them seriously and seek immediate help. If you ever find yourself in a crisis situation, please don't hesitate to contact a helpline or emergency services. They are trained to provide the necessary support and ensure your safety.

In terms of self-harm, it's essential to find healthier ways to cope with your emotions. Engaging in activities that bring you joy, such as hobbies, exercise, or spending time outdoors, can help distract from negative thoughts and emotions. Additionally, consider exploring mindfulness techniques, like deep breathing exercises or meditation, to ground yourself in the present moment.

Remember, recovery takes time, and it's important to be patient with yourself. Healing from depression is a journey, and there will be ups and downs along the way. Celebrate even the smallest victories and give yourself credit for the progress you make, no matter how small it may seem.

Please know that you are not alone, and there is support available to you. Keep reaching out, keep seeking help, and never give up hope. You deserve to live a fulfilling life, and with the right support and resources, it is possible to find healing and happiness.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 I'm really sorry to hear that you're experiencing such intense thoughts and feelings. It sounds like you're going through a very difficult time as a new mom. Remember, you're not alone in this. There are people who care about you and want to support you.

It's important to acknowledge the guilt and exhaustion that comes with being a working mom. It's challenging to balance work and motherhood, especially when your partner is at home with the baby. You're doing your best, and it's okay to ask for help when you need it. You're not expected to do everything by yourself.

The intrusive thoughts you mentioned can be distressing and overwhelming. They don't reflect who you are as a person. It's natural to feel overwhelmed at times, but there are resources available to help you navigate this journey.

If you ever feel like you're in danger of hurting yourself or your baby, please reach out to a trusted friend, family member, or mental health professional immediately. They can provide the immediate assistance you need.

You're doing an amazing job, even though it may not always feel like it. Be kind to yourself and remember that seeking help is a sign of strength. You deserve support and understanding as you navigate this challenging period of your life.

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 I understand how overwhelming and frustrating it can be to deal with anxiety, especially when it starts affecting your relationships and daily activities. It's important to remember that you're not alone in this, and there are steps you can take to manage your anxiety.

One technique that might help is deep breathing exercises. When you start feeling anxious, try taking slow, deep breaths in through your nose and out through your mouth. This can help calm your nervous system and reduce the intensity of your anxiety symptoms.

Another strategy is to challenge negative thoughts that contribute to your anxiety. Often, we have automatic thoughts that fuel our anxiety, such as "everyone is judging me" or "I'm going to embarrass myself." Take a moment to question these thoughts and ask yourself if there's any evidence to support them. Usually, we find that these fears are not based on reality.

Additionally, gradual exposure to the situations that trigger your anxiety can be helpful. Instead of avoiding haircuts altogether, consider starting with small steps, like making an appointment but not showing up, then gradually working your way up to getting a cut. This allows you to face your fears in a controlled manner, building confidence along the way.

Remember, managing anxiety takes time and patience. Be kind to yourself throughout this process and celebrate even the smallest victories. If you ever need someone to talk to, don't hesitate to reach out to a trusted friend or family member. They can provide valuable support and understanding.

 I'm glad to hear that you've taken the step to seek help for your anxiety. It's completely normal to feel unsure about starting medication, especially if you're new to managing anxiety. The decision to start medication is a personal one, and it's important to consider what feels right for you.

Many people find that anxiety medication can be helpful in managing their symptoms, particularly when therapy alone isn't providing enough relief. Medication can provide additional support and help you regain control over your anxiety. However, it's important to remember that everyone's experience with medication is unique, so what works for one person may not work for another.

In terms of your concerns about being on medication long-term, it's important to approach it with an open mind. Anxiety is a chronic condition for many people, and managing it often involves a combination of therapy and medication. While it's natural to worry about being on medication indefinitely, remember that you can always reassess your needs as time goes on. Many people find that their medication needs change over time, and they may need to adjust their dosage or switch to a different medication.

Regarding your experience with pain medication, it's common for people to underutilize their prescribed pain medication. Pain medications are typically prescribed for acute pain, such as after surgery, and are not meant to be taken regularly for chronic pain. If you're concerned about taking medication for anxiety, it's important to understand that anxiety medication is prescribed to manage symptoms, not to mask them. When taken as prescribed, medication can help reduce anxiety symptoms and improve your overall well-being.

It's also worth mentioning that therapy can be incredibly beneficial for managing anxiety. Therapy provides a safe space for you to explore the root causes of your anxiety, develop coping strategies, and learn new ways to manage your symptoms. Many people find that therapy alone is enough to address their anxiety, while others find that a combination of therapy and medication works best for them.

Remember, this is just general advice, and it's important to consult with a mental health professional who can provide personalized guidance based on your specific needs. They will be able to assess your situation more thoroughly and make recommendations tailored to you.

I hope this helps, and I wish you all the best on your journey towards managing your anxiety. Remember to be patient with yourself, as finding the right approach may take time. You're taking an important step by seeking help, and with the right support, you can learn to effectively manage your anxiety and regain control over your life.

 I understand how difficult it is to navigate through these emotions and experiences, especially when they seem to be impacting your daily life. It takes a lot of courage to reach out and share your feelings, so I commend you for taking this step.

Given what you've shared, it's important to remember that everyone's journey is unique, and there isn't a one-size-fits-all solution. However, there are some general suggestions that might be helpful as you move forward:

1. Self-reflection: Take some time to reflect on your emotions and try to identify any patterns or triggers that may contribute to your sadness and inner pain. This self-awareness can provide valuable insights into the underlying causes of your current state.

2. Seek support: While it can be challenging to know who to trust, consider confiding in someone you feel comfortable with. This could be a close friend, family member, or even a support group. 3. Professional help: If you find that your symptoms persist despite your efforts, it might be beneficial to seek professional help from a mental health therapist. 4. Self-care: Prioritize activities that bring you joy and relaxation. Engaging in hobbies, practicing mindfulness techniques, getting regular exercise, maintaining a healthy diet, and ensuring adequate sleep can all contribute positively to your overall well-being.

i m a very confident guy i m very socal and can speak to anyone but for some reason i have this weird like i dunno anxiety attack thing so basically i could be having a random chat but quite often if someone say something that could be deemed wrong or bad or something that i could potentually be hiding when im not i go bright red really hot itchy and im all awkward and can bairly make word out even if they arnt even talking to me directly here is some example i wa talking to a fellow work mate about our personal preference in woman i said i prefer smaller petite girl with small boob and he said nahh i dissagree it like a child s body and boom my brain somehow ha this attack that make me seem like i like kid or another one could be playing never have i ever and someone say never have i ever sucked a cock and boom it ll happen itll make it look like im hiding the fact that i ve sucked a cock which i havent could be anything along those line and i hate it and i always try my hardest to avoid any convos which could lead to anything like that i m a prison officer so sometimes they bring up corrupt officer in convos and it hit me so hard and they look at me funny like im hiding the fact that i m corrupt which i m not i hate it what is this and how can i fix it

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you're experiencing a specific type of anxiety, particularly when certain topics are brought up. This anxiety is causing physical symptoms such as turning bright red, feeling itchy, and becoming awkward. It's important to remember that you're not alone in experiencing this, and there are steps you can take to manage it.

One approach that may be helpful is cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT). CBT focuses on identifying and challenging the negative thoughts and beliefs that contribute to anxiety. In your case, it could involve examining the underlying assumptions or fears that arise when someone mentions something "wrong" or "bad." By questioning these thoughts and replacing them with more realistic and balanced ones, you can begin to change your response.

Additionally, practicing relaxation techniques like deep breathing exercises, progressive muscle relaxation, or mindfulness meditation can help reduce the physical symptoms of anxiety. These techniques can be learned through self-help resources, online tutorials, or even smartphone apps.

In social situations, it might be beneficial to gradually expose yourself to conversations that trigger your anxiety. Start with smaller steps, such as engaging in casual chats about neutral topics, and gradually work your way up to more sensitive subjects. Remember to be patient with yourself and celebrate each small victory along the way.

While I'm not a mental health professional, I hope these suggestions provide you with some guidance and support. If you find that your anxiety continues to significantly impact your daily life, it would be beneficial to seek help from a qualified mental health expert who can provide personalized strategies and interventions tailored to your specific needs.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

 I understand how difficult it is to feel this way, and I want you to know that there is hope for healing and finding peace. It's important to remember that you are not alone in your struggles, and there are people who care about your well-being. While I'm not a mental health professional, I can offer some suggestions that might be helpful.

1. Reach out for support: Consider confiding in someone you trust, such as a close friend or family member. Opening up about your feelings can provide a sense of relief and help you feel less isolated.

2. Seek professional help: A mental health professional, such as a therapist or counselor, can offer guidance and support tailored to your specific needs. They can help you explore the underlying causes of your distress and develop coping strategies to manage it.

3. Engage in self-care activities: Taking care of yourself physically, emotionally, and mentally is crucial. This can include getting enough sleep, eating nutritious meals, engaging in activities you enjoy, and practicing relaxation techniques like deep breathing or meditation.

4. Challenge negative thoughts: Our thoughts can greatly influence our emotions and behaviors. Try to identify any negative or self-harming thoughts that may be contributing to your distress. Once you've identified them, challenge their validity and replace them with more positive and realistic perspectives.

5. Connect with supportive communities: Consider joining online forums or support groups where you can connect with others who may have similar experiences. Sharing your story and hearing from others can provide validation, understanding, and encouragement.

Remember, healing takes time, and it's important to be patient with yourself throughout this process. You deserve compassion and support, and there are people who genuinely care about your well-being.

i miss my life before this depressive episode idk if you can even call it an episode anymore it s been over year i don t think i ll ever be the same and that destroys me inside i miss 0 9 and 0 0 up until september i wa truly happy and just coasting through life so content i wa so happy and life wa so simple especially during the 0 0 lockdown all i had to do during the lockdown wa watch load of anime and random netflix show explore new music stay up all night and do nothing i even had time to explore my childlike side by doing load of painting and drawing using kiddie paint and colouring book my mental health wa great too i had no eating disorder no depression no school work my anxiety and ocd wa minimal and i wasn t so deeply lonely like i am now i can literally just hear a song smell a smell or taste a good that i experienced to during that period and i will burst out in tear because i miss not being depressed so much now even if i do try and enjoy life like i did back then and be carefree it ll never be the same because my anxiety and depression have quite literally destroyed me from the inside now i ll never be able to enjoy life like that again i had never been in a relationship and that didn t bother me at all now i ve still never been in a relationship and it make me feel unloveable and ugly i always hear people at school talking about their relationship and date and stuff and even though i don t want a boyfriend that bad i still feel like i m missing out on a key part of the teenage experience but still to be honest i m not that keen on a relationship i really just want to be happy anyway all that s left to do is die i have my plan in place and i have a date and method at least i can say that i experienced true happiness and one point in my life i guess

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 I'm really sorry to hear that you're feeling this way. It sounds like you've been through a lot and it's understandable that you're struggling with your current state of depression. While I can't provide professional help, I want you to know that there are people who care about you and want to support you.

It's important to remember that everyone's journey is unique, and what worked for others may not work for you. However, there are some steps you can take to try and improve your mental health. Firstly, reaching out to someone you trust, like a friend or family member, can be a good starting point. They can offer emotional support and may even be able to connect you with additional resources.

Additionally, engaging in activities that bring you joy and fulfillment can make a difference. While it might feel difficult right now, try to find small moments of happiness in your daily life. It could be something as simple as going for a walk, listening to music, or pursuing a hobby you enjoy. Remember, the goal is to focus on self-care and do things that make you feel good, even if it's just for a short period of time.

Furthermore, consider seeking professional help from a mental health expert. They can provide you with personalized guidance and treatment options tailored to your specific needs. Therapy, medication, or a combination of both might be beneficial in managing your depression.

Lastly, please remember that you are not alone in this. There are people who genuinely care about your well-being and want to see you heal. Keep reaching out, keep seeking support, and never give up hope. You deserve happiness and the chance to live a fulfilling life.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]
