[Question]
hi i am male i used to have a very emotional side but for the last year or so i am not able to feel sad especially for others sympathy i used to cry when my best friend cried to me about her break up but now i couldn t shed a single tear during my grandfather death i hated the feeling did i stop loving my grandfather even then why didn t i feel sad when i saw my mother cry she is the first person i don t want to see cry off late i feel it s affecting my friendship a well just to be clear it s not a overall numbness i still feel happiness anger and other emotion but this is really frustrating especially when i am getting into a relationship for the first time in my life i keep questioning my love for people i keep asking myself if i can t feel sad for them do i really love them

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 I understand how difficult it is to experience this change in your emotional state, especially when it comes to sadness and sympathy. It's important to remember that everyone's emotional experiences can vary, and it's not uncommon for emotions to shift or lessen over time. While I'm not a mental health expert, I can offer some suggestions that might be helpful for you.

Firstly, it could be beneficial to explore any potential underlying causes for these changes in your emotional state. Sometimes, emotional numbness or difficulty feeling sadness can be linked to past traumas, stress, or other significant life events. Reflecting on these experiences and seeking support from trusted friends, family members, or even a professional counselor may provide valuable insights into your current emotional state.

Additionally, practicing self-compassion is crucial during this time. Remember that it's okay to feel differently than before, and there's no right or wrong way to experience emotions. Allow yourself to acknowledge and accept your current emotional state without judgment.

Engaging in activities that used to bring you joy or fulfillment, even if you don't feel the same intensity, can also be helpful. While it may not immediately alleviate your emotional numbness, it can serve as a reminder of the range of emotions you are capable of experiencing.

Lastly, open communication with your loved ones about what you're going through can foster understanding and empathy. Letting them know that you're currently experiencing difficulty with sadness and sympathy can help them approach you with patience and support.

Remember, these suggestions are not meant to replace professional advice but rather serve as possible avenues for self-exploration. If you feel overwhelmed or believe your emotional state is significantly impacting your daily life, it would be beneficial to seek guidance from a mental health expert who can provide personalized support tailored to your specific needs.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[Question]
i m talking to my psych on monday and i want to do some research into what might work for me i have frequent mild panic attack infrequent but still kind of like once a week once every week severe panic attack and constant anxiety i ve tried a bunch of anxiety med but haven t really found any that worked for me however i haven t tried any in year so there s a chance i ve grown a i wa about during most of my trial and it s been a good year since then so what are were your favorite thanks

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 I'm here to support you in finding the right tools to manage your anxiety and panic attacks. It's great that you're open to exploring different options, even if some medications didn't work for you in the past. Here are a few suggestions:

1. Breathing exercises: Deep breathing techniques can help calm your body during panic attacks. Practice taking slow, deep breaths in through your nose, holding it for a few seconds, and then exhaling slowly through your mouth.

2. Grounding techniques: When you feel anxious or panicked, try grounding yourself by focusing on your senses. Look around and name five things you can see, four things you can touch, three things you can hear, two things you can smell, and one thing you can taste. This exercise helps bring your attention back to the present moment.

3. Cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT): CBT is a type of therapy that focuses on identifying and challenging negative thought patterns. It can be helpful in managing anxiety and panic attacks. Consider finding a therapist who specializes in CBT or exploring online resources for self-help CBT programs.

4. Lifestyle changes: Certain lifestyle factors can contribute to anxiety, such as lack of sleep, excessive caffeine intake, and stress. Taking care of your physical health by getting enough rest, eating balanced meals, and engaging in regular exercise can positively impact your mental well-being.

Remember, everyone's journey is unique, so what works for one person may not work for another. Be patient with yourself as you explore different strategies, and don't hesitate to reach out for professional help if needed. You deserve to live a life free from constant anxiety and panic attacks.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[Question]
i am not sure if this is possible and i appreciate any information a few year ago i wa diagnosed with clinical anxiety depression and adhd i wa relieved and terrified and so sad it took me until adulthood to learn this about myself i began medicating under the direction of my psychiatrist after about a year i changed from zoloft to prozac due to weight gain i began experiencing night sweat for the first time in my life about month ago it wa sporadic for month or so than became nightly now it ha worsened to the point that i wake up multiple time a night to change sheet and pajama i m not wetting the bed but truly soaking it through with my sweat in a degree room with minimal blanket i ve had to replace plastic bed protector mattress cover and even my mattress i believe i am having panic attack while i am asleep and i am unable to remember them assuming i would remember having a nightmare at the same time or be semi lucid what could paralyze me in sleep while having normal pleasant dream and cause excessive night sweat my change in medication did not correlate with the onset or increase in the night sweat i have had blood test mri pulmonary exam allergy test ultra sound and more no western doctor or my psychiatrist ha been able to find anything unusual that would explain the night sweat tl dr extreme night sweat begin in adulthood with no obvious cause desperately looking for advice on what might help edit 9 f

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 I understand how overwhelming and frustrating it must be to experience such intense night sweats, especially when they are affecting your sleep quality and causing discomfort. It's important to remember that everyone's experience with night sweats is unique, and there may not always be a clear explanation for why they occur. However, there are some strategies that you can try to help manage your symptoms.

1. Keeping a cool sleeping environment: Maintaining a comfortable temperature in your bedroom can help reduce the likelihood of excessive sweating. Consider using fans, air conditioning, or even placing a damp cloth under your sheets to help regulate the temperature.

2. Wearing breathable pajamas: Choose loose-fitting, breathable fabrics for your nightwear. Natural materials like cotton or bamboo allow for better airflow and prevent trapping heat against your skin.

3. Avoiding caffeine and alcohol before bed: Both caffeine and alcohol can increase your heart rate and body temperature, which may contribute to night sweats. Try to limit your consumption of these substances, especially in the evening hours.

4. Practicing relaxation techniques: Engaging in relaxation exercises such as deep breathing, progressive muscle relaxation, or meditation can help calm your mind and body before bed. These techniques can also assist in reducing anxiety and promoting a more peaceful sleep.

5. Establishing a consistent bedtime routine: Creating a relaxing routine before bed can signal to your body that it's time to wind down. This might include activities such as reading a book, taking a warm bath, or listening to calming music.

6. Seeking emotional support: Night sweats can sometimes be linked to stress and anxiety. It may be helpful to explore any underlying emotional issues that could be contributing to your symptoms. Consider reaching out to a therapist or counselor who can provide guidance and support in addressing these concerns.

Remember, these suggestions are not meant to replace professional advice but rather offer some general ideas that you can try at home. If your night sweats persist or worsen, it's important to discuss them with your psychiatrist or primary care physician. They will be able to provide a more comprehensive evaluation and recommend appropriate treatment options tailored to your specific needs.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

i m slipping into a deep deep depression divorce failed business losing my home many regret etc etc i need a direction in my life i can focus and work hard on but i don t even know where to begin i need someone to help me a there s no way i can do it myself i have adhd so my mind go in a million direction all the time is a good life coach what i need

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 I understand how overwhelming it can feel to be in a place where you're struggling with depression, a failed marriage, and financial setbacks. It's completely normal to have moments of regret. You've been through a lot, and it's okay to take some time to process these emotions.

When it comes to finding direction in your life, it can be helpful to start by reflecting on what truly brings you joy and fulfillment. What are the activities or interests that make you lose track of time? These could provide clues about what brings meaning to your life.

Additionally, setting small, achievable goals for yourself can help create a sense of purpose and accomplishment. Breaking down larger tasks into smaller steps makes them more manageable and less overwhelming. Celebrating each milestone along the way can boost your confidence and motivation.

While I'm not a professional therapist, I do understand the struggles that come with ADHD. It can indeed make it challenging to focus on one thing for too long. One strategy that might be useful is the Pomodoro Technique. This involves breaking your work into 25-minute intervals, followed by short breaks. After completing four intervals, you take a longer break. This approach helps maintain focus and prevents burnout.

Remember, healing takes time, and it's important to be patient with yourself. Surrounding yourself with supportive friends, family, or even online communities can provide valuable emotional support. If you ever feel overwhelmed or need someone to talk to, don't hesitate to reach out.

Please keep in mind that my suggestions are based on general knowledge and personal experience. If you're feeling particularly unwell or need professional guidance, it's essential to seek help from a mental health expert who can provide personalized care.

For example, if studying is difficult, try breaking it down into smaller tasks like reading a chapter or completing a few pages. By taking small steps, it can feel less daunting and more manageable.

Additionally, it might be helpful to explore new activities or hobbies that you haven't tried before. Sometimes, engaging in something different can reignite our passion or at least provide a fresh perspective. You could consider joining a club, taking up a new sport, or even volunteering for a cause that resonates with you.

While it's natural to feel hesitant about seeking help, remember that there are people who care about your well-being and want to support you. Lastly, try to challenge negative thoughts and beliefs about yourself. Remember that everyone has their own unique strengths and qualities, and nobody is perfect. [Question]
hey everyone i am just curious if anyone ha also suffered from this type of anxiety i will get anxiety and panic about one thing and after coping and learning to overcome this anxiety my anxiety tends to hyper fixate on something else to worry about im wondering if anyone else ha dealt with this and how they stopped this cycle im currently on sertraline and buspirone and attend therapy a well for anxiety and panic disorder

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It can be incredibly challenging to manage anxiety, especially when it feels like it's constantly shifting its focus onto new concerns. It's important to remember that you're not alone in experiencing this cycle of anxiety, as many individuals struggle with similar issues.

One strategy that may help break the cycle is practicing mindfulness. Mindfulness involves being fully present in the moment, without judgment or attachment to thoughts or worries. By focusing on the present moment, you can redirect your attention away from anxious thoughts and bring yourself back to the reality of the here and now.

Additionally, cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) techniques can be beneficial for managing anxiety. CBT helps identify and challenge negative thought patterns that contribute to anxiety. By examining the evidence for and against these thoughts, you can develop more balanced and realistic perspectives.

Self-care is also crucial in managing anxiety. Engaging in activities that bring you joy and relaxation, such as exercise, hobbies, or spending time in nature, can help reduce stress levels and promote a sense of well-being. Prioritizing self-care allows you to recharge and build resilience against anxiety triggers.

Remember, everyone's journey with anxiety is unique, so finding what works best for you may take some trial and error. Be patient with yourself and celebrate small victories along the way. With time, support, and effective coping strategies, it is possible to break free from the cycle of anxiety and live a fulfilling life.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[Question]
tw depression okay besties i need some help opinion ab my struggle with brushing my hair i currently have really bad knot in my hair and i m hispanic white and my hair is so thick and curly i don t understand how to properly take care of it and i haven t brushed my hair

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 i understand how overwhelming it can be to manage thick, curly hair, especially when you're dealing with a knot. It's important to approach this challenge with patience and care. Here are some suggestions that may help:

1. Start by detangling the hair: Before brushing, use your fingers to gently loosen any tangles. This will make the process smoother and reduce the risk of damage.

2. Apply a leave-in conditioner: Applying a leave-in conditioner can help soften the hair and make it easier to brush. Look for a product specifically designed for thick, curly hair.

3. Divide the hair into sections: Instead of trying to brush the entire head at once, divide the hair into smaller sections. Focus on one section at a time, brushing from the ends up to the roots.

4. Use a wide-tooth comb: A wide-tooth comb is gentler on thick, curly hair. Start at the ends and work your way up, being careful not to pull too hard.

5. Take breaks if needed: Brushing thick, curly hair can be exhausting, so don't hesitate to take breaks if you feel overwhelmed. Give yourself time to rest and come back to it when you're ready.

Remember, taking care of your hair is a journey, and it may take some time to find what works best for you. Be patient with yourself and celebrate small victories along the way.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]
